The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will be setting milestones in conjunction with the MARA to monitor the development of the industry in relation to:
. improvements in competence and ethical standards;
. the extent of MIA industry coverage and its performance in the industry regulation role; and
. changes to consumer awareness that would support a less regulated environment.

The extension of statutory self-regulation until March 2003 will provide an opportunity for some of the important industry values being promoted by the MIA and the MARA to be more firmly entrenched in industry practice.
Many industry stakeholders have confirmed, to the review, the need for continued improvements in the ethical standards and competence in the industry and protection available to consumers.

This bill includes two new measures to this end. Other measures will be addressed through amendments which require more complex drafting, which I expect to introduce next year, and through regulation amendments.
The bill includes amendments to make publication requirements relating to decisions by the MARA to cancel or suspend an agent's registration more cost-effective.

Currently the MARA is required to publish full details of any decisions to cancel or suspend an agent's registration in the Saturday edition of a national daily publication, including the evidence for its decisions and its findings on any material details of fact.

Although the intentions behind this requirement are to protect existing and potential clients and to promote agent and community understanding of appropriate ethical standards in the industry, in practice, the requirement has resulted in costly advertisements swamped by excessive detail, with little visual impact and little communicative value.

The amendments in this bill maintain the basic requirements that the MARA should publish its decisions to suspend or cancel an agent's registration and the grounds for its decisions in prescribed publications.

However, the MARA will no longer be required to publish full details of the evidence and its findings on material facts relevant to the decision, saving money for the industry body and thus ultimately agents and consumers.

The amendments will also give the MARA the discretionary power to publish some or all of this detailed information about cancellation or suspension decisions in an expanded variety of formats and methods of publication relevant to its target audiences, including on the Internet and in specialist newspapers.
The amendments will also give protection to other persons publishing in good faith a copy or fair summary of the MARA's decisions.

Together, these amendments will mean that the MARA will be able to use appropriate channels to communicate more effectively—to clients, agents and the general community—its decisions to suspend or cancel an agent's registration.

This bill also provides the MARA with powers to ensure that clients of inactive and deceased agents are not unduly disadvantaged by the agent becoming inactive or as a result of the death of the agent.

Therefore, the MARA will be able to require certain agents—for example, those whose registration has been suspended or cancelled—to provide copies of relevant client documents to the MARA for forwarding to clients.

This will enable clients to continue their cases with another agent or to manage their cases themselves, ensuring that critical deadlines in relation to a client's visa applications or reviews of applications are not ignored.
The MARA's ability to do this will be discretionary. There may be cases such as multi-agent practices in which the MARA does not need to intervene.
However, the relevance of this power was highlighted by the recent closure of the largest migration advice firm in Australia.
Fortunately, this company voluntarily made files available to the MARA.

However, if such a situation occurs after the commencement of the bill, and if the firm or agent does not make files available to the MARA voluntarily, the powers in this bill will provide a basis for the MARA to require that relevant documents be copied, and that those copies be given to clients.

The closure of this particular migration agency is being closely evaluated by my Department and the MARA to identify any further issues which may need to be addressed within the industry regulation arrangements.

In conclusion, this bill extends the protection that is available to consumers under the current arrangements and will continue the progress that has been achieved in the last 18 months towards enhancing competence and ethical standards in the industry.
I commend this bill to the Main Committee. I present the explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: —It is Christmas time, so I will not speak for long and I will be very nice to the minister this morning. The Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1999 is another bill—amongst just about every one that has come up for debate in either this or any other chamber—that we have supported. We support the sunset clause being extended until March 2003. I have had the opportunity on a number of occasions to talk to the industry association, and I am quite convinced that they are doing everything they can to ensure that the migration advice industry is cleaned up as best it can be.

speech.para: I am aware that, from time to time, there is a lot of public concern, and I am sure that my colleague the honourable member for Chifley will say later that there are always complaints about shonky migration agents which come to members of parliament. In most cases—probably in every case—they are not registered and are not fair dinkum. We need to make sure that justice is seen to be done and that appropriate consumer regulations and mechanisms are in place to protect what are most often people who cannot speak the language, do not know our systems and are very easily conned into handing over money for something that, in many cases, is of no value to them.

This bill simply extends the current arrangements for the regulation of the migration advice industry. It also amends the Migration Act to provide more efficient methods of warning the public of the suspension or cancellation of an agent's registration and enables the Migration Agents Registration Authority to protect the rights and interests of people whose migration agent has died or has been deregistered.

I recently went to one of MARA's conferences in Brisbane, I think, and I was quite impressed with their education schemes for making some of their registered migration agents aware of what it is that they are supposed to do. I noticed that something like 40 per cent of all registered migration agents are lawyers. That is a problem in the sense that lawyers do not particularly want to be part of any industry body but their own. In this case, it really is an important facet of the migration advice industry that everybody should be involved in a whole group. To be truthful, I do not see why they do not join the industry association because the industry association are the ones that in effect form MARA under this legislation and, if you want to be a migration agent, you come under that umbrella as well.

I noticed that something like 38 per cent of complaints received by MARA concerned lawyers, although it does not appear that MARA referred any of these complaints to a disciplinary body for lawyers. It is a bit hard for a disciplinary body of lawyers to make some sort of value judgment as to whether someone in the migration area has made a mistake or done the wrong thing. That is something the immigration minister might be prepared to look at. He will get support from me on that for sure.

The opposition supports this bill. We thank the minister and those in the minister's office for the extra information they gave to Senator Cooney and Senator McKiernan, who were quite interested in knowing some of the details of the review. I have had a good look at the review, and I think it has been very wide ranging. It has come up with a number of better initiatives for making this system work better. Given that this self-regulatory scheme has been in place for only a year, it is sensible that we extend it for a few more years. I noticed as well that it will be reviewed again during the next three years. I do not propose to say anything more about this. It is a measure that the opposition welcomes.

In conclusion, all my dealings with the industry association have been good. They are always willing to talk to me and, I am sure, other members of parliament as well. I think that migration agents do not deserve to have the reputation now that they have had in the past. Yes, there are some shonks still around and, yes, I am concerned that only 24 per cent of registered migration agents are actually part of the industry body. It is the industry body that are looking at further education and the development of expertise, so they might want to redouble their efforts in that regard. But, given that they have only been travelling for a year, I think we can give them another three years and then review them again to see how they are going. I will leave it at that and remind the minister again that, on the last day we are here, we are again in a bipartisan mode.

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to rise to support the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1999 today and to commend the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs for bringing it forward. The minister has proved himself to be a very capable and effective minister in managing a fairly difficult portfolio, not the least of which has involved the events that have emerged over the last several years and, more particularly, in the last couple of months. This is part of an effective administration that, for the most part, has received bipartisan support. I think that is an appropriate way to go. It is difficult to manage at the best of times. There are lots of international sensitivities. I was very pleased to note that the shadow minister for immigration, the honourable member for Bowman, also supported the bill today. It is good to see such bipartisan bonhomie and Christmas spirit at this time.

speech.para: In terms of the provisions of the legislation, it is appropriate that the sunset clause be extended for a further three years and that the voluntary code which has been in existence be given time to operate and to show its effectiveness. There is no doubt that the management of migration agents is a difficult area. In the past, in the area of migration agents, as the shadow minister said, there has been a tendency for a lot of shonks to operate. People have been encouraged to use every trick in the book in order to stay here.

During our inquiry into the treatment of refugees, there was an open admission by a lot of the people who were dealing with refugees that some of the agents clearly did not have ethical standards. This piece of legislation is about standards in the industry. It is about ensuring appropriate supervision of agents. It also provides the ability to take away the registration of agents where they have demonstrated unethical behaviour. It is not in the interests of those migrants who come here or those who are going through the process of applying for citizenship or migration to this country to be fooled in terms of the appropriate channels or requirements.

There are four registered migration agents operating in my electorate of Cook. Jian Wang and Ying Feng Lui operate from the suburb of Miranda, and John Shanahan and Bobby Halim are based in Sylvania. These agents assist friends and family members of my constituents who need advice concerning visa categories for relatives' applications, and also asylum seekers wanting assistance in putting their claim together.

The operations of these agencies are assisted and overseen by MARA, the Migration Agents Registration Authority. Since March 1998, when the minister appointed the Migration Institute of Australia to act as the Migration Agents Registration Authority, it has performed well in ensuring that migration agents have served their clients well. Minister, seeing that you are in the chamber, it is appropriate to congratulate you on taking that step in terms of registration. It is also appropriate that we would want to see more of the agents belonging to the association. That is the appropriate way to go if they want to undertake the necessary training that is available to them.

MARA has focused on the ongoing education of agents, not on exercising coercive punishments such as by imposing fines or other penalties. The ultimate sanction is that their registration is taken away. It is similar in many ways to the situation involving travel agents, where a self-regulating authority is in place and where deregistration can occur. The authority has managed entry into the group of registered agents, their re-registration, the fielding of complaints, the initiation of disciplinary proceedings, and generally the maintenance of industry standards.

The role of MARA is set out in section 316 of the Migration Act. It produces an annual report and has a code of conduct. It also produces newsletters for members and continuing professional development kits and mediation kits, and runs a web site for which it provides fact sheets.

During the last 12 months the authority has held eight mediations. The authority believes that the mediations are an overall success enabling the parties themselves to establish an agreement to their dispute. Of the eight mediations held to date, five achieved an agreement to which both parties adhered. From these five successfully mediated agreements, five have resulted in the authority deciding to take no further action on the complaint.

This bill has certainly enhanced the authority's power in regulating the industry. It allows for the better warning of clients and migration agents by indicating a particular agency's standing within the group, overseen by MARA, and by providing information on whether an agent is fully accredited. It safeguards the rights of clients of deregistered or deceased agents.

In August 1999, over 3,000 people were left unrepresented in their applications to the department of immigration and appeal bodies for various classes of visas when Barlow and Co. went out of business. Obviously they had spent a lot of money in the process of their claims and paid it to Barlow. Suddenly Barlow went out of existence and all assistance that had been given in the past just went for nought through the business collapse of this organisation.

In response, this bill contains measures designed to ensure that people whose migration agent has been deregistered will be able to continue with their migration or review applications without disadvantage, and I think that is a significant step forward. There may be further amendments to part 3 of the Migration Act in response to this collapse and these amendments will be included in an omnibus bill at a later date. In summary, I commend the minister for bringing forward this legislation. It is appropriate that we continue the close supervision of agents. This voluntary code is appearing to work. We would encourage more agents to belong to the association to get all the benefits of the training and newsletters et cetera. It is good to see such bipartisan agreement on such an important part of migration activities in this country.

talk.start.para: —I notice that the Christmas spirit has been referred to. I hope honourable members do not think I am a heathen by virtue of my contribution. I certainly do support this bill but I would be less than honest if I did not say that I do have quite a number of reservations about the activities of migration agents. Very briefly, in 1997 the government commenced statutory self-regulation of the migration advice industry and appointed the Migration Agents Registration Authority, MARA, to establish a regulatory body for the industry with the aim to eventually move towards self-regulation.

speech.para: The bill expands the Migration Agents Registration Authority's powers to access files where the registration of a migration agent is cancelled or suspended; where the agent has become incapacitated, dies or is voluntarily deregistered; or where a migration agent's registration expires; and to provide copies of relevant documents to clients. This will, of course, maintain and strengthen consumer protection and contribute to the integrity of the migration and humanitarian programs by promoting an ethical and competent migration advice industry. I certainly think that this is a very worthy objective, but I think the agents risk their industry if they fail to rigorously ensure that they have an ethical industry, including the self-regulatory body MARA.

It is important to recognise that currently MARA has jurisdiction only over registered migration agents. In the majority of cases the only disciplinary sanction that MARA has against a registered migration agent is to cancel or suspend their registration. Once an agent is deregistered, he or she is no longer within the jurisdiction of MARA.

As the shadow minister has already mentioned, 40 per cent of migration agents in 1998 were lawyers and 38 per cent of the complaints arose from those agents. It seems to me to be absolutely absurd that a solicitor acting as a solicitor can be disciplined by his professional body for errors or whatever, but, notwithstanding the fact that MARA has the power to refer these matters to the legal disciplinary bodies, no referrals have occurred to date in relation to acting as a migration agent. I make this point: from my experience of the constituents that come through my front door, I do not see that they are less exploited by migration agents who happen to be solicitors than by the ones that are not solicitors. I think this is a blight on the legal profession and it is a real weakness. I do not think a solicitor should be secure in his legal profession irrespective of what he does as a migration agent. That is completely abhorrent to me and I think it is abhorrent to any sense of fairness and any sense of justice.

The honourable member for Cook, who made a contribution to this debate, referred again to the case of Barlow and Co., Australia's largest legal practice specialising in migration, which collapsed. They had some 3,000 clients on their books, some from my electorate. If a firm of solicitors collapses and they have moneys in their care on behalf of clients, that money is protected. If a legal practice that wholly or partly practises in migration law collapses, why should the migration clients of that practice not be indemnified as well? I would be very interested, as I always am, to hear what the minister or the department may have to say about this matter. There are contradictions. If my assertions are wrong in this I am more than happy to be advised otherwise, but I suspect they are not.

I see a lot of people about migration issues in my electorate. In fact, I can say that approximately—and we do keep records of it—80 per cent of the people who walk through my door come to me about migration matters. I will just say this: I have always had a practice in my office of trying to tell them exactly what the honest situation is. Some people would love to hear that miracles can be done or that, through the intervention of their federal member, we will be able to ensure that they stay here. There have been some exceptional cases, and I would be less than gracious if I did not acknowledge the fact that the department has always bent over backwards to assist me in those cases. But when people want to apply for a refugee status or a protection visa and we know that they have absolutely no basis for sustaining it, then we tell them so.

Indeed, I came from the old school which said it was never a backbencher's responsibility to say no, it was the minister's. I have changed that in terms of migration—we are now no longer sending on requests for ministerial discretion when we are more than confident that it will not be exercised. In fact, we tell constituents now that we will not deal with their case when they are being handled by a migration agent.

Sometimes people come here on a visitor's visa, stay for a while and find that they love Australia. They have been reunited with some relatives or they see the marvellous opportunities here, and they want to apply to become permanent residents. I am quite convinced they would make excellent citizens, but they cannot apply. So they go to a business migration agent, who will probably get them to apply for a protection visa. If the protection visa is not approved, there is an opportunity then to appeal to the Refugee Review Tribunal, then the Federal Court or, indeed, to seek exercise of the minister's discretion. That will take about two years and will also take up several thousand dollars.

This is what really upsets me about migration agents. The point I want to make is that the migration agents that act this way do so totally dishonestly. The only way it can be justified is if the client says, `Can you leave me here for two years? I am prepared to pay several thousand dollars for that privilege,' and the migration agent replies, `I will exercise every option available to you but in the knowledge that you will never succeed.' But of course that is not what they are told and that is not the way they apply.

I really resent it if, when every option has been exercised, the migration agent sends them off to my office to ask me then to make representations. Perhaps, Mr Deputy Speaker, coming from Tasmania you do not have so much experience with it—

talk.start.para: —I do.

—That is interesting. These people, I feel, in the main are very vulnerable. I am intensely proud to have in my electorate a lot of Filipinos—the largest concentration in any LGA—and also Indians, Pakistanis, Fijians and Lebanese. All these groups of migrants tend to get awfully exploited. They make a wonderful contribution not only to my electorate but also to this nation, but they are being exploited by migration agents, in my humble opinion.

speech.para: Essentially, when the system of migration agents was first established, the idea was that people could go to them for a reasonable fee and get some advice or assistance in filling in a form and lodging it with the department. That is an appropriate role. But I do not think it is appropriate that the stricter migration guidelines in this country are used to exploit people, to extract money from them by way of fees in the knowledge that their case is absolutely hopeless. I am not suggesting that for us to tighten up in this area is easy, but everyone in this game has a vested interest in a much cleaner system of migration agents and would benefit from it.

I turn now to my last complaint. Let us remember that 40 per cent of migration agents are lawyers. There is a schedule of fees that a solicitor or a barrister can charge. I think that the disciplinary body would not be too happy, for example, with a charge of $500 for one letter. Yet, by and large, when solicitors practise as migration agents there appears to be no control whatsoever over the fees that they can charge for certain actions. Again it is a case of double standards. If someone is legally qualified, the overwhelming disciplinary mantle should be that of the legal profession. I would suggest to the legal profession that it is outrageous that a solicitor can be disciplined for some of his charges when acting in the law other than in migration, but when acting as a migration agent he is allowed to charge—without penalty, without review, without discipline—whatever he likes.

To summarise: the opposition is supporting this measure. In my own electorate I have quite some experience of migration agents. Just this year we have changed some of our practices, after a number of years, in response to problems with migration agents. I would like to see the continuation of migration agents but there is a desperate need for even tougher measures. In particular, it is necessary to get away from the double standards that apply to members of the legal profession when they act as migration agents.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Immigration and Multicultural Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —in reply—I would like first to thank my colleagues for their support for the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1999 . It would be of grave concern to me were the sunset clause to operate and the existing arrangements that we have for supervision to fall. I do want to thank the member for Bowman, as well as the members for Cook and Chifley, for their support for the legislation.

speech.para: I will not repeat the comments I made in the second reading speech—they stand as printed—but I particularly want the member for Chifley to know that I share many of the concerns he raised. Let me just say that. I and the shadow minister are both members of the legal profession.

talk.start.para: —I was gracious enough not to mention that!

—Quite frankly, I emphasise from time to time, and I will do it here, that the legal profession has certain values, ethics. I can see one of my colleagues over there who has even taught law. Some of those ethics that I was taught when I was a young practitioner involved not only my obligation to my client, but also my obligation to fellow practitioners and to the court.

speech.para: I often say when I speak to migration agents, because there is no court that applies to them, that there is a wider obligation they have to the community of which they are a part that requires some cognisance of the broader national interest. That means that you have a migration program which operates with integrity, a program in which you do not set out to find ways and means to undermine it. I have to say that I think—and members will know that I hold this view very strongly—that there are some who have no cognisance of the wider national interest. If they see a loophole, they believe it is there to be exploited, regardless of its impact.

I have to say that I am very much aware of some of the unconscionable charging arrangements that some members of the profession are involved in. I want members of this committee to know that I have personally raised matters with the Law Society of New South Wales relating to the conduct of members of the legal profession. I have not waited for them to be considered by MARA. I believe that they were of sufficient concern that a representative body of the profession ought to have been active in taking them up.

Members will know—and this relates to the comments from the member for Chifley—that not all migration agents are involved in the practice of misleading their clients. Sometimes they tell them, because the client comes in simply wanting a work opportunity, that by using the system they can get them a year or two. Some advertisements, of some members of the profession, for people to come forward who have exhausted all other remedies—even been to other agents—say, `If you come and see me you can join my class action, which I have under way right now, which will enable you to apply lawfully for another bridging visa.'

Members may not know the background reasons for why bridging visas have to operate as they do. It is a very simple reason: we have detention facilities normally for about 900 people in Australia. If we were to arrest and hold every unlawful that we located and everybody involved in legal proceedings or making applications to me or using the tribunal processes, we would have to have detention facilities for 10,000 people. Bridging visas are not issued to enable people to go out and get work. They are issued for a very practical reason: that is, unless we have some basis upon which they can be held in the community while they undertake their lawful entitlements, we cannot properly detain them. That is the only alternative that remains available to us.

Why did I raise another matter with the Law Society of New South Wales? I came across a letter that had been written by a solicitor who had initiated a class action on behalf of clients. All of the class actions that we have had to date have failed. There are some that are still before the courts, but all of those where we have had a judicial decision taken have failed. The letter I saw in this case from a member of the legal profession was to the clients of a failed class action, encouraging them to send another $250 so that they could be part of an appeal. I guess that is not unreasonable. When the solicitor then says that, in addition, there will be no accounting for the money that is paid by the client and, further, there will be no refund of any of the money paid, I consider that highly unethical. I guess I was right because the Law Society counselled the solicitor. He was told to tell the client that he would account for the money.

There are problems associated with running an administrative scheme, and MARA is in a difficult position. They are in the same position that we face in relation to any of the so-called rights that people have, such as the right to practise. If we are going to take away somebody's livelihood, there has to be evidence. The reason we cannot act against half the shonks is that they cover their tracks so carefully. The people involved, particularly if their actions have failed, may have been removed from Australia. The prospect of getting evidence against some of these people is extremely difficult. Somebody might say, `Try to push the envelope.' You push the envelope and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act operates. They are back off to the courts.

This supervision really involves the protection of shonks. The difficulty we have is that there is not a ready appreciation in this field that ethics are required. Every time I go to the MIA—they are almost sick of me coming through the door—I tell them that we need ethical standards. You have to have an appreciation that in this field there is a wider Australian public interest.

I think it is important in discussing these issues for people to know that there is a will on the part of the government to do something about it. I will look for any creative ideas to enable us to do it more effectively. I am sure, as the honourable member for Bowman indicated in his remarks, that there will be support from the agents who are ethical. I am sure there is a desire on the part of the MIA to deal with these matters, but, as has been said, when 70 per cent of the industry do not bother to join the industry body and you get the ethical people in it and the others outside, the task is fairly difficult.

I want to conclude by saying that I appreciated the compliments paid to me by the member for Cook, and I thank him for that. But I particularly want to thank the member for Chifley, not because he is lightening the load in my office but because I think the approach that he is taking is absolutely right. It is the approach I took as a backbencher in not misleading people as to the outcomes that can be achieved. I think it is just exploitation of the vulnerable to hold out hope where none exists. Yet we know that the exploitation of the vulnerable is to hold out hope and to take more money off them. A far better approach by disciplinary bodies, including the legal disciplinary bodies, is not in challenging the scheme because it might require solicitors to come in and be a part of it, but ensuring that appropriate standards are met would speak well of the law societies and similar bodies and I think would lift the esteem in which the profession is held in the eyes of the public, where they could be far more proactive. I hope some of my friends in the profession one day have an opportunity to read these remarks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 repeals section 22 of the War Crimes Act 1945. The act was amended in 1989 prior to the fall of the Iron Curtain to enable trial in Australia with respect to conduct engaged in during World War II in Europe. Although the usual practice would have been to extradite persons accused of such crimes to the country where the crimes occurred, it was considered at the time to be politically unacceptable to extradite persons to countries behind the then so-called Iron Curtain. Some years ago the Iron Curtain fell, fortunately, and many of the republics—including Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania—are now independent states and have been accepted as members of the Council of Europe. Australia has in the past been prepared to enter into extradition arrangements with any country that is a member of the council.

The government is actively pursuing the possibility of establishing modern extradition arrangements with many of these newly independent states. However, even if a modern extradition relationship were in place, it would still be impossible for those countries to comply with an extradition request while section 22 of the War Crimes Act remains in force in our country. Effectively, section 22 of the act provides that, where a person's extradition from Australia is sought for conduct covered by the act, no surrender for extradition is possible unless the requesting country establishes a prima facie case. Thus, notwithstanding a modern extradition relationship with these countries, if the offence for which the extradition sought is a war crime, then the requesting state must provide a prima facie case.

Because of the differences between civil code and common law countries, the practical effect is that it would be virtually impossible for a civil code jurisdiction to successfully seek the extradition of a person suspected of a war crime. The concept of a prima facie case is determining sufficiency of evidence, and it is one to which most common law countries are accustomed. However, those countries which operate under a civil code system—for example, Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania—do not use this test in criminal proceedings. The practical issue is that the laws of evidence in common law systems are such as to make it very difficult for a civil code jurisdiction to supply evidence in an admissible form.
The repeal of section 22 will remove the fundamental barrier to Australia's cooperation with the international community in relation to suspected war criminals.

This is not to say that extradition of a suspected war criminal would be automatic. Any requests for the extradition of a suspected war criminal would be subject to the general extradition arrangement with the requesting country. Such arrangement must include all the usual safeguards spelt out in the Extradition Act 1988. All that the amendment will do is to remove an additional onerous requirement that relates only to the extradition of war criminals. This government sees no reason in principle why this practical impediment to the extradition of war criminals should be retained.
The amendment to the act will not have any financial impact. I commend the bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill to this committee.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports this legislation, the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 . By way of background, it is useful to put ourselves back into the frame of mind that existed at the time the provisions relating to extradition of alleged war criminals from the Second World War were enacted. It was a period where the world was convulsed with outrage in relation to the atrocities that had been conducted in Germany and in the countries that Germany had occupied—the forced deportation of many millions of people and the extermination of millions in the gas chambers of the Nazi war machine. There was a sense that the world had to enact a framework that would deal with those who had perpetrated such atrocities.

speech.para: Nonetheless, there was another mind-set that also applied and that was a fundamental distrust of the legal regimes of many Eastern European states. That was because, at that time, those states were part of the larger empire of the Soviet Union or certainly subject to their dominion. It was a widely held view that those regimes were prone to distort historical records and that their legal systems provided no framework that was adequate for this country to respect in relation to those charged with criminal or quasi-political offences of this nature. I only say quasi-political in the sense that they arose out of the conflagration of war. The Soviet regime, having itself lost, I think, something in the order of 20 million dead as a result of resisting a German invasion, was felt to have such an antipathy to those who might be charged with offences that the normal protections of the legal system could not be guaranteed.

In the Cold War climate that I grew up in as a young man, there was still the lasting aftermath of a campaign in Australia to have the Communist Party of Australia proscribed as an illegal organisation and a widely held view that it would have been improper for us to send back to Eastern European countries persons against whom charges even of this nature were made to face trial and the penalties that would have applied in those eastern bloc countries, unless we ourselves formed a view that there was a substantial and probably conclusive case against them.

That was the framework in which the extradition provisions that currently apply were made, which require, before a surrender to another country of a person against whom extradition is sought for these offences, that an Australian tribunal must first satisfy itself in relation to the prima facie case that exists against that person. That is a not insubstantial hurdle when we are dealing with very different legal regimes. It is not an insubstantial hurdle even when we are dealing with similar legal regimes that understand a common law system of what actually comprises a prima facie case. But when we are dealing with civil law countries—and most of Europe does operate on a civil law environment—the knowledge base to put together effectively an application for extradition is limited. That has been in part the root reason why, in the law of extradition generally, we have moved away from the requirement for the establishment of a prima facie case.

There is a hold-over in this area which still remains on the statute books. It is now thought appropriate to, in a sense, align the provisions that relate to extradition for the general run of criminal offences with those that we will now be enacting with respect to alleged war crimes. That will facilitate more readily the surrender to countries which were formerly part of the Soviet bloc, including Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, of persons who are asserted by those jurisdictions to be in Australia, if any such assertion is made, and against whom they assert evidence is available to establish proof of guilt in relation to atrocities that occurred during the Second World War.

My briefing to date from the department is that no intention to file an extradition application currently stands. But it may well be that, over time, these provisions are exercised. I know that my colleague from Melbourne Ports has put questions on the Notice Paper in relation to a Mr Ozols and he has raised this matter with me. It may well be that the authorities in the country where he is alleged to have been a significant and senior participant in a number of atrocities may feel it appropriate to seek such extradition. There may be others. By changing the law in this manner we do facilitate that.

There are always arguments that ought to be taken seriously with respect to those who have come to Australia after World War II that amongst those persons were some who were not seeking to make a new home in Australia as a result of circumstances which we would all regard as perfectly understandable and justifiable but who, it is asserted, had been involved in these atrocities. In those circumstances, I think the whole Australian community would want to see those persons brought to justice, whether in this country or overseas.

Of course, when we did have the regime that formerly applied—that is, the prima facie regime—when the former Labor government came to office and was confronted with substantial allegations that there were persons living amongst the Australian community who had been involved with these events, the response that was then made was to establish a special investigation unit which was resourced to assess those matters and to prepare them for prosecution. A number of prosecutions did take place.

For a variety of reasons the basis upon which the SIU was established was that, rather than facilitate extradition, the trials should take place in Australia. That, in itself, gave rise to a whole series of complexities. Perhaps that was a bad decision, in retrospect. It is easy to be wise in hindsight, but perhaps it was a bad decision because of the difficulties in bringing witnesses to Australia and in establishing proof of materials held on files in those countries which were then still subject to Soviet domination.

A whole range of other such issues did make those trials particularly difficult and, as history will show, either acquittals or discharges for reasons of ill health or the age of the accused meant that we obtained no convictions. I must say that I do not think that outcome has stilled the disquiet amongst those who suffered at the hands of the Nazi war machine. Perhaps there are still some living amongst us in this community who should be better placed on trial and account to history for the actions they undertook.

The opposition is content to support these changes. We accept that the international legal circumstances in respect of both the former Soviet Union and the states which were subject to it have changed and that we should apply the same regime to those extraditions as apply in other areas. That is not to say that somebody charged with an extraditable offence is entirely without some opportunity for an examination of the matters alleged against them. There are a series of processes, often much litigated already in this country, where people are made subject to extradition requests. The extradition requests are subject to a range of discretionary matters in the end which the minister must consider before a surrender is made.

So it is not as if a case cannot be made either administratively or later at a political level to the minister that a surrender request must be acceded to if there are some circumstances wherein it is asserted that the legal regime in those countries is still not appropriate to enable a fair trial. There may indeed be some argument advanced to that effect in respect of particular matters. Nonetheless, I think the generality of this legislation is now most appropriate, and it indeed fits with the way in which the international community has seen appropriate to regard extradition and, as importantly, reflects the continuing abhorrence by the Australian community of the Holocaust and those who gave rise to it.

With those remarks, I indicate that the opposition does support this legislation. As I said, there are many things that perhaps with hindsight we might reflect on in relation to the conduct of matters previously. But it is not an area where I am content to say, as some amongst the Australian community do, that these are events in the dim, distant past which should be allowed to fade from memory. To the extent that properly based evidence is available to establish the fact of willed participation in these terrible events, I do not believe we, as a parliament, should ever stand in the way of the proper trial and punishment of such persons.

talk.start.para: —The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 provides for the repeal of section 22 of the War Crimes Act. The effect of the repeal of the legislation will be to facilitate extradition proceedings of suspected World War II war criminals residing in Australia to countries with civil legal codes and, in particular, to former Soviet bloc countries. The bill will bring the evidentiary requirements for the extradition of suspected war criminals into line with those of other criminal offences in Australia, subject to the Extradition Act 1988.

speech.para: Section 22 of the War Crimes Act was originally introduced in response to concerns over judicial processes in the former Warsaw Pact countries. Prior to the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War, there were concerns that individuals who faced extradition to countries in the Eastern bloc would not be subjected to the same judicial standards that could be expected in the West. As a result, an additional requirement to establish a prima facie case in the Australian courts prior to successful extradition of alleged war criminals was introduced. While the prima facie requirement was in response to concerns about Soviet bloc countries, it also had the effect of applying to all civil law jurisdictions. A prima facie case is a feature of the judicial system in common law countries and ensures that, at a relatively early stage of proceedings, there is sufficient evidence to establish grounds for a preliminary case against the accused. However, it is not commonly employed in civil law countries and, because of the significant differences in the evidentiary procedures of the two codes, it has been almost impossible in practice for countries with civil codes to extradite suspected war criminals from Australia.

With the end of the Cold War and the breakup of the Soviet empire, judicial processes have considerably improved in what was once the Eastern bloc. The Baltic states of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, as well as Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Russia, have all reformed their legal systems, and their criminal and civil justice systems have met requirements for admission into the Council of Europe.

Australia has, in the past, been prepared to establish extradition arrangements with any country that is a member of the Council of Europe, such as France and Germany. The rationale then for demanding that a higher threshold of guilt be established prior to extradition of suspected war criminals to the Eastern bloc is no longer evident.

Section 22, however, continues to create impediments in establishing extradition arrangements with civil law countries that may have cause to request the extradition of suspected war criminals from the Second World War residing in Australia. The repeal of this provision for extra evidentiary requirements for war criminals prior to extradition will also bring Australia into line with war crime extradition procedures in Europe. Neither Britain nor Western European countries retain additional evidentiary requirements in respect of the extradition of war criminals. As has been referred to, the rights of individuals in Australia facing extradition continue to be safeguarded by the Extradition Act under which the Attorney-General also retains a residual discretion to decline the surrender of a person to a foreign jurisdiction.

The effect then of the legislation will be to remove a significant impediment to the extradition of suspected Nazi war criminals. It is a further attempt to reduce the possibility that Australia should be used as a haven for war criminals or individuals who are suspected of having committed crimes against humanity and are sought by other jurisdictions.

The issue of suspected war criminals residing in our country has received considerable prominence in Australian public debate in the whole period since the Second World War. Indeed, as early as 1947, allegations were made in Australian newspapers that former Nazis and Nazi collaborators had managed to enter Australia.

From the 1950s to the 1970s, law enforcement authorities received a number of reports about individuals suspected of involvement in war crimes during World War II. There were also a number of extradition requests from communist countries. None of these requests were acceded to.

According to the final report of the Special Investigations Unit of the Attorney-General's Department, the US also failed to receive significant assistance from Australia in response to their requests in the course of the eighties. Throughout the 1980s, the Office of Special Investigation of the US Justice Department made a number of requests for assistance with suspected war criminals residing in Australia who were potential witnesses to investigations in the United States.

In 1986, ABC Radio broadcast a series of programs called Nazis in Australia. The series, by journalist Mark Aarons, contained a number of documented serious allegations about suspected Nazi war criminals who had come to Australia since the Second World War. Following Mr Aarons's revelations, the Australian government appointed Mr Andrew Menzies to conduct a review of allegations relating to the presence of Nazi war criminals in Australia. Mr Menzies found that it was more likely than not that a significant number of persons who committed serious war crimes did enter Australia and that appropriate further action needed to be taken.

As a result of the Menzies finding, the government amended the War Crimes Act to enable war crimes to be dealt with in Australian courts. An investigative unit, to be known as the Special Investigations Unit or SIU, of the Attorney-General's Department was established under the direction of Mr Robert Greenwood QC. The SIU operated from 1987 to 1992. During that period it conducted 841 investigations into suspected war criminals residing in Australia. Of the 841 investigations, 819 were suspended due to a number of factors, including that the suspects were found to have been deceased, living abroad or unfit to stand trial. In other cases, investigators were unable to substantiate the allegations, there was insufficient evidence and in some cases the accused had been previously convicted abroad.

There were, however, four cases that were referred to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. Three of these cases went to trial. Two were unsuccessful, a third was abandoned on medical grounds and, in 1992, the SIU was closed down by the Labor government before charges could be laid against the fourth suspect. In 1995, Robert Greenwood, the former director of the SIU, launched a strong attack on the then government, accusing it of actively frustrating and undermining the operation of the SIU.

It is interesting that the then Labor finance minister, Peter Walsh, in his autobiography, Confessions of a failed finance minister, said that, as finance minister, he tried to prevent the establishment of the SIU and hoped that `the crazy exercise would be terminated'. It is instructive that Mr Walsh made this additional claim:
Whatever moral force the argument for the War Crimes bill had, was somewhat diluted by the contemporary behaviour of the Israeli Army in Gaza and the West Bank . . .
One would hope that former Senator Walsh's views did not play a role in the previous government's decision to close down the SIU.

It did become apparent, however, from the three trials that were conducted, that it is very difficult to successfully prosecute in Australia individuals who are alleged to have committed crimes against humanity in other countries, particularly when those crimes occurred some time ago.

Australia is not the only country to face the challenge of bringing to justice suspected war criminals who have migrated to their country. Both Canada and the US have been confronted with numerous cases of suspected war criminals in their jurisdiction. They have responded to those cases with a variety of measures, including revocation of citizenship and deportation of more than 50 individuals found to have been engaged in crimes against humanity.

In Australia, there is still public concern over suspected war criminals residing here. The most prominent of those persons is a Mr Konrad Kalejs. Mr Kalejs immigrated to Australia in 1950 and gained citizenship in 1957. He travelled to the US soon afterwards and became a successful property developer. In 1984, he was arrested in the US, and deportation proceedings were commenced against him. He is accused by the US Justice Department of having been a senior officer in the Latvian auxiliary security police, a pro-Nazi unit that killed tens of thousands of people during World War II.
In 1994, the US Federal Court of Appeals determined that Mr Kalejs should be deported to Australia. According to the judge, Mr Kalejs was:

. . . a key officer in a unit that killed tens of thousands of innocents. Kalejs and his unit had two other duties besides killing Jews in the Riga ghetto . . . The unit joined the German SS in so-called anti-partisan activity, which was little more than a cover for arresting and murdering civilians.
In 1994, Mr Kalejs was deported to Australia. In 1995, he left Australia for Canada where he was arrested, declared persona non grata, and, in June 1995, returned to Australia.

In September 1995, Kalejs was again arrested at Toronto airport after making a second trip there, and he was detained by authorities until his immigration hearing. On 18 August 1997, a Canadian immigration tribunal ordered Mr Kalejs deported back to Australia and found that he had been `an accomplice to the acts of murder, forcible confinement, enslavement and torture.' The tribunal found that Mr Kalejs had `violated the laws of war and committed war crimes, or crimes against humanity.' The Canadian tribunal also found that Mr Kalejs `was a party to the offences of murder and kidnapping.'

Mr Kalejs was deported back to Australia. The office of the minister for justice has advised that the DPP concluded that the evidence available here is insufficient to launch a successful criminal prosecution against Konrad Kalejs.

In November 1997, Latvia made a mutual assistance request to Australia for documents concerning genocide and war crimes involving Mr Kalejs. I am advised by the minister's office that, following a comprehensive review of relevant departmental files, a considerable amount of documentation on Mr Kalejs was provided to the Latvian authorities in response to their request for assistance. Australia also has had discussions with Latvia and Lithuania with a view to establishing extradition arrangements with those countries.

It is important to note that this legislation is not in response to any one case or individual; rather, it is designed to regularise our extradition arrangements in respect of accused World War II criminals who may be seeking sanctuary in Australia. As the minister has said, this move sends out a strong message internationally that Australia is not, and will not be, a haven for suspected World War II war criminals.

The challenge for our society is to find a way in which we can work with the international community to ensure that principles of justice apply to those involved in crimes against humanity who may seek a safe haven or refuge in Australia. It is a tragic reality of the second half of this century that crimes against humanity, atrocities, war crimes and attempted genocide did not end with the end of the Second World War. Indeed, if we look at Rwanda, Cambodia, the attempted extermination of people in Iraq, and more recently in East Timor, it is apparent that such acts of carnage have not abated as the 20th century draws to a close.
The moral imperative from the extermination of more than six million Jews during World War II was to never forget but, as time draws on, the memory of the international community does drift.

There are some who argue that many of those who were engaged in war crimes during World War II are now old men, that time has moved on and that we should forget the past. There are those who argue that it is too difficult and too costly to bring to justice men who have committed crimes many years ago. Indeed, there are some who even argue that we should not concern ourselves with crimes committed in a foreign land.

But the rule of law is not some fashionable policy from which we can pick and choose. If a man lives in our midst who is responsible for the deaths of one or 30,000 civilians, do we not have a responsibility to see him brought to justice? Can there really be time lines on mass murder? Can we seriously evoke a forgive and forget response to those who have committed crimes against humanity?
Dr Colin Rubenstein, the executive director of the Australia/Israel and Jewish Affairs Council, argues:
. . . neither the passage of time nor vagaries of location should become pretexts for inaction in the pursuit of justice.

If individuals who reside in this country have committed crimes against humanity in other countries, then we should take every measure possible to assist in bringing those individuals to justice. As Mark Baker, the Melbourne University history academic, has written:
A passport is not a confessional box where one secures absolution from guilt.

In the period following World War II, inadequate vetting procedures created favourable circumstances for suspected war criminals to seek sanctuary in Australia. If a crime can be graduated, it is hard to envision a more heinous crime than that committed by individuals who have been complicit in genocide, the deliberate effort to destroy a national, racial or ethnic population. Future generations will not judge us well if we do not take every measure possible to bring to justice those who have committed crimes against humanity. This bill is an important part of that process. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

talk.start.para: —The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 , concerning the extradition of war criminals, will be some small consolation to the Australian public and even smaller consolation to those who still suffer with memories of the atrocities committed during World War II, many of whom are my constituents. As has been outlined by the member for Kooyong, there are strong reasons of legal uniformity for supporting this bill, which changes the level of legal proof needed by countries seeking extradition of war criminals from Australia. Bipartisan support for this bill should not lead the government, particularly the Minister for Justice or the Attorney-General, to think that there is approval for what some regard as their inaction in tackling these issues of war crimes since this government has been in office.

speech.para: In all fairness to this government I would say, however, that it is probably not the only one whose handling of this issue is legally, ethically and politically problematic. Our inaction in Australia is currently affecting our reputation overseas. Only last weekend, the influential US current affairs program 20/20, watched by an estimated 60 million viewers around America and hosted by America's premier current affairs interviewer Barbara Walters, alleged that mass murderers are able to live comfortably in Australia without fear of prosecution, as compared with the United States, which has continued to regularly prosecute and deport Nazi war criminals.

The current government's response to these queries since it has been in office was summed up by the Attorney-General in 1997. Indeed, it was taken up again by the minister for justice in her various media appearances on Monday in response to the 20/20 program. I would sum up their attitude as insouciance and inaction. In my view it is, quite frankly, embarrassing. The minister told the 7.30 Report that she would not look into these matters herself. Rather, in a bureaucratic sidestep, she said that this was a matter for the Australian Federal Police. She knows full well that the Australian Federal Police are under the clear impression that the government does not want this matter raised or prosecutions recommenced.

One gets the impression from the media appearances of the minister for justice that she has kept herself in splendid ignorance of some of these issues: benign neglect, the blind eye to the telescope. At least that is how she came across in her response to the 20/20 program, when Mr O'Brien interviewed her on the 7.30 Report. She was asked whether she supported a past government's decision in 1992 to disband the Special Investigations Unit. The SIU was set up within the Attorney-General's portfolio to investigate and prosecute, under the amended War Crimes Act 1945, any individuals found to be residing in Australia who had committed crimes against humanity during World War II.

We know that the minister for justice was not in government then, but she claims to have been advised that one of the cases that had been put by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, regarded by the unit as its strongest case and above the three cases which had been unsuccessful, did not proceed because the Director of Public Prosecutions decided there was not enough evidence to proceed.

We know that this is simply not true. The minister and the government know that. After three unsuccessful prosecutions, mounting pressure from the then Liberal opposition and growing expenditure, policy fatigue set in. The then government announced that it would close the Special Investigations Unit. With only weeks until the closure of the unit, something of a battle developed between the SIU and the then Attorney-General and the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions over the fourth and most significant war crimes case, PU38, involving a gentleman called Karlis Ozols, who has been mentioned a number of times by previous Attorneys, so I am not doing anything unusual in mentioning his name here. Ozols was a volunteer in the SS auxiliary, the Arajs Commando, and still lives peacefully in Melbourne. He should and could have been dealt with by Australia's legislation if the recommendation of senior independent counsel, Mr Peter Faris QC, had been addressed. This is in direct juxtaposition to the minister's ill-advised comments that nothing further could be done on this matter, according to her advice.

On 28 June 1992, Faris concluded his advice to the DPP, estimating that, while some research still needed to be completed, it would take only another three months to have all of the evidence prepared for trial against Ozols, that there was already a prima facie case for mass murder and war crimes. Mr Faris set out a number of charges and advised, `It would be wrong to shut the investigation down. Justice demands the investigation be completed.' The DPP sought to continue the investigation but the then Attorney-General resisted and referred the matter to the Australian Federal Police where the file has remained in a drawer. No prosecution was ever commenced; the investigation was not completed.

In March 1996, of course, the government changed hands and in 1997 a statement by the present Attorney-General, Daryl Williams, announced that the case was concluded and that there was little chance of success in pursuing it to finality. The documentation surrounding Karlis Ozols remained tightly restricted by the Federal Police and the Attorney-General's Department until late 1997. Indeed, the full circumstances surrounding Ozols was never put in the final report of the SIU to parliament.

In June 1992, Faris, the former head of the NCA, had gone through all of the charges, particularly as far as Mr Ozols was concerned. It is interesting to consider the three charges that he specifically put. Let us have a look at some of them. The first was that Mr Ozols was involved in killing people himself, as a lieutenant in the Latvian SD at Maley Trostenets. Mr Faris said there was a prima facie case that Ozols had committed war crimes between July 1942 and 27 September 1943 at Maley Trostenets. The second charge that he suggested there was a prima facie case for advancing was in the Minsk ghetto where, as the commander of the Arajs Commando, Ozols was directly and indirectly responsible for deaths.

Finally, Faris said that between 8 and 9 February 1943, Ozols and other members of the Latvian Arajs Commando under his command assisted the Germans in killing more than 2,000 Jews in the Slutzk ghetto. Mr Faris and the SIU were not concerned about issues of identification which were so important in other cases that have been considered around the world, including the very famous issue of Mr Ivan Demjanjuk and his identity. First of all, Mr Faris established that there were overseas witnesses and then he established that there were local witnesses, some of whom I have spoken to personally. Some of them were about 12 or 13 and had known Mr Ozols all of their lives.

Thirdly, was a killing order from SS Obersturmfuhrer Strauch in which Hilfsbeamten or supernumerary Ozols name was specifically included as a person responsible for various killings. Finally, in the state court of Hamburg in 1979, the German government requested an interview and extradition of Mr Ozols to participate in various other trials that were taking place against members of the Arajs Commando. The German court established all of the details of Mr Ozols' presence at all of the three incidents that Mr Faris QC recommended, via the DPP, to the Attorney-General as the reason for a prima facie case being necessary.

In North Queensland recently, a person who some would describe as an elderly pensioner has been charged as the alleged perpetrator of the murder of two children that took place more than 20 years ago. No-one in this parliament would suggest that because this gentleman is an age pensioner no charges should be pursued against him. The statute of limitations does not apply, according to any of us, to the charge of murder, and I think it is simply being consistent that we ought to apply it in these cases ourselves. The member for Kooyong spoke of the moral imperative that drives a democratic society like Australia in these kinds of issues, in remembering why we participated in that great struggle for democracy during the Second World War. I believe that this moral imperative should have been behind all of our actions in dealing with all of these issues, including the government's welcome amendment to repeal section 22 of the War Crimes Act 1945.

If people feel that perhaps these issues do not apply to Australia, I remind them of events that took place immediately after the dropping of the Special Investigations Unit and the policy fatigue that took place at that time. I go first to what happened in Bosnia. The war crimes that took place there led to the United Nations setting up special war crimes investigators. Ironically, the person who is now most prominent in seeking prosecutions against war criminals in Bosnia and Serbia is our own Graham Blewitt, who was the last head of the Special Investigations Unit that was too early sent into legal oblivion by a previous government and whose work should have been taken up by the current government.

If we look at the disgraceful situation perpetrated by Indonesian military authorities in East Timor after the 30 August referendum, the widespread international community view and the view of the UN Human Rights Commissioner is that war crimes and crimes against humanity may have been perpetrated in East Timor by the then military authorities of Indonesia. If people feel that in dropping our interest in war crimes we have in any way contributed to this expectation in some areas of the international community that war crimes and crimes against humanity such as those perpetrated in Bosnia and East Timor have in any way been lessened, we stand partially to blame for that development.

I conclude by indicating my support for these amendments to the War Crimes Act 1945. I hope that the now democratic countries of the Baltic take the opportunity to use Australia's new ability to assist them in extraditing the two or three people who have been talked about internationally as people who may be in Australia and who, according to the democratic and historical experience of those Baltic countries, it is seen as essential to bring to those countries for trials and examination of their activities during World War II against citizens of those countries. I commend this amendment to the War Crimes Act 1945.

talk.start.para: —I think we all agree that we do not want to see Australia a haven for war criminals. The War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 that we are debating here today will lead to the repeal of section 22 of the War Crimes Act. That will mean there will no longer be any need to establish a prima facie case prior to the extradition of people overseas for trial on issues in relation to alleged war crimes.

speech.para: One of the important principles involved is that international boundaries should not allow a person to evade criminal justice. One of the things that is referred to again and again in the literature surrounding this legislation is the fact that over the years we have seen, across the world, closed borders. Those closed borders, and the lack of ability to view proceedings behind those borders, have resulted in and facilitated fairly lurid media headlines from time to time when it has not been possible for a trial to proceed because of allegations occurring on one side of the boundary and people existing on the other side of the boundary.

For example, I refer to some of the headlines that have gone before in the Australian Jewish News such as that on August 27 this year. It said, `Nazis in Australia: too late, says expert', and the article refers to media revelations that Australia secretly recruited known SS members, former Nazi storm-troopers and Nazi party members to work here as scientists and technicians after World War II. The same article states:
Not every German was a Nazi and not every Nazi was a war criminal.
But there is in that kind of a lurid presentation of the details a clear imputation that some of those people may have been involved in war crimes.
What is a war crime? I will not go into all the details here. A war crime is defined in sections 6, 7 and 8 of the War Crimes Act. I am quoting here from an article by Gillian Triggs:
A serious crime is a war crime if it was:
(a) committed:
(i) in the course of political, racist or religious persecution; or
(ii) with the intent to destroy in whole or in part a national, ethnic, racial or religious group, as such, and
(b) committed in the territory of a country when the country was involved in a war or when the territory of the country was subject to an occupation.
War is defined by section 5 to mean war `in so far as it occurred in Europe in the period beginning on 1 September 1939 and ending on 8 May 1945'.

That basically sets out what the War Crimes Act is dealing with, but I can go on into the article by Gillian Triggs and look at the consideration of people where, as I stated earlier, the allegations involved activities that were alleged to have occurred on the other side of borders that were for some time closed. I want to refer now to a case involving Mr Polyukhovich and the article by Gillian Triggs. She says:

Mr Polyukhovich was seventy-two when, on 26 January, 1990, he was charged with nine offences (later amended to eighteen) alleging the murder of twenty-four men, women and children and of having been knowingly involved in the murder of 850 Jews in the Ukraine between 1941 and 1943. The day before he was to appear in the Adelaide Magistrates Court committal proceedings, Polyukhovich was shot in the chest and wounded. This delayed proceedings but did not cause them to be terminated.
A litte further on in the article she says:
Polyukhovich was committed to stand trial in the Supreme Court of South Australia on two charges relating to the killings of six people.
In other words, prima facie evidence was found to exist in that case—that is, prima facie evidence as established within the Australian judicial system.

The subsequent trial of Polyukhovich in the Supreme Court of South Australia came to an abrupt end when the indictments were quashed for lack of evidence. Apparently the court was not satisfied as to the credibility of the witnesses and was not prepared to allow such evidence as there was to go to the jury.

That case indicates an example in which prima facie evidence was found to exist. What we are dealing with here is the idea that it is not necessary to find prima facie evidence, and that is certainly the case in all other matters apart from allegations of war crimes. In all other matters, dealings between international authorities occur because of extradition treaties on which there is no necessary evidence at all. All that is needed to be established is that there is a domestic law in Australia—in other words, an extradition agreement with that other country—and that there is an allegation and a request from that country for that to proceed.

When we consider the needs for extradition, under the Extradition Act 1988, which will become the relevant act once section 22 of the War Crimes Act is repealed, there are protections in place. I want to refer in particular to the protections given to the Attorney-General. Before someone can be extradited, the Attorney-General has to be satisfied that there is no extradition objection in relation to the offence; that on surrender to the extradition country the person will not be subjected to torture; and that, where the offence is punishable by a penalty of death, special circumstances apply.

The Attorney-General must consider one of the following alternatives: one, the person will not be tried for the offence; two, if the person is tried for the offence, the death penalty will not be imposed on the person; three, if the death penalty is imposed on the person, it will not be carried out. Further, the Attorney-General can satisfy himself or herself that a special assurance has been given in relation to the person. I am not covering all the specific details, but the Attorney-General also has discretion to consider that the person should be surrendered in relation to the particular offence.

The international principle is that extradition proceedings have no function in determining whether someone is guilty or innocent. They are simply an administrative matter. Is the person concerned liable under our law to be surrendered up to another country to face trial? In other words, do we recognise their law and do they recognise ours? That is the basis on which an extradition agreement exists or does not exist.

In the past there have been questions about whether people extradited to Warsaw Pact countries, under the former Warsaw Pact, would be provided with a fair trial. We have all heard allegations—it is probably a clear fact—that under those regimes there were political juntas and military juntas conducting show trials. There would be real concern in the mind of the average Australian that those things would have been occurring. However, since the collapse of the Soviet empire and the break-up of Yugoslavia, many ex-Warsaw Pact nations are now moving towards the mainstream in terms of their governance and in terms of their legal system.

I think we would all have seen the notes that have been issued illustrating this bill which list a number of countries from that area. Is there any reason why we should not develop extradition agreements under our law with those particular countries? Can we establish those agreements? I would submit that we should be setting up those agreements. As I said, those borders have been an impediment for years to the proper review of people's behaviour or crimes alleged against them. Now is the opportunity to clear the air on those issues. Therefore, obviously I commend this bill.

We would have to establish an extradition treaty with those nations before we would be obliged under our law to give up someone. I had a particular look at some of those ex-Warsaw Pact nations. I asked myself, `What other ones are there, apart from the ones listed as moving down this path? Are there some recalcitrant ones?' Obviously there are. For example, what is the position with Serbia? Would Australians in general like to see someone extradited to Serbia? I think many people would be concerned about that. Clearly that is not going to happen because we do not have any extradition agreement with them. We have nothing within our domestic law that would require an Attorney-General to give up someone for trial in Serbia.

As these nations move towards the mainstream in terms of their governance, then we can make these agreements and we can then see justice done. Where there is an allegation made, it can be followed down the burrow. People can then determine whether there is a case to answer under the appropriate regime, and the decision can be made.

There have been some examples. In 1997, Latvia sought documents regarding alleged genocide and war crimes by Mr Kalejs during the Second World War. It is possible that Latvia may seek to extradite Mr Kalejs when it has completed its examination of all this material, and an extradition treaty would facilitate that. By removing this requirement for an examination of prima facie evidence in such a case, Australia is clearing the way for such a thing to occur.
Another example occurred when Lithuania sought information from Australia on alleged war crimes by Antanas Gudelis of Adelaide. A report in the Australian Jewish News of 30 July 1999 says:

Mr Gudelis, 87, immigrated from Germany with his wife 50 years ago and became an Australian citizen. He is suspected of the mass murder of civilians in the Lithuania town of Kupiskis during World War II.
The article goes on to say:

Mr Gudelis was previously investigated by Australia's Special Investigations Unit (SIU), but prosecution did not proceed. The SIU was set up in 1987 following allegations of alleged war criminals . . . It investigated a number of cases of alleged war criminals under the War Crimes Act 1945.

Four cases were referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions, but none was successfully prosecuted before the SIU was closed down by the Federal Government in 1992. The government has been criticised since then for lack of political will on the issue of alleged war criminals living in Australia.
I think this legislation puts an end to that kind of criticism.

talk.start.para: —Why?

—Because it provides the opportunity for these people to be tried in areas where these things are alleged to have occurred. It is reasonable for people to continue to actively question the government on this issue because it is a very emotional one, but I do think that by opening the door for scrutiny overseas by the very people who are making the allegations, and by not keeping this impediment of prima facie evidence, Australia is coming to a position that is workable. I would be interested to hear what the member opposite has to say about that.

speech.para: It is a situation that is difficult. It has raised tremendous expectations in the past, only to have them dashed. I do not anticipate that that sort of thing is going to stop in future just because we do this, particularly so many years after the fact, but the point is, steps are being taken.
