I would like to reiterate that the end of the communist era means that these issues can be opened up to scrutiny. They can be tried in an environment which Australians would have trust in and would believe to be accurate. It means that the system in those countries is increasingly transparent. We in Australia need to facilitate the flow of justice in relation to these very emotional issues.

As I said, this bill opens the way for that to occur. I welcome the support that has been forthcoming from members opposite in relation to it. It is important that such an emotional issue does not degenerate into a point scoring exercise. On the whole, that kind of temptation has been avoided in the past, and I hope that will continue to be the case in the future. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to speak on the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 , and I support the legislation. However, I have to say this legislation is long overdue because it is at least seven years since most of the Iron Curtain countries gained their independence and yet we are only just acting on this matter now. It has been far too slow in coming.

speech.para: Both sides of the House are, I think, open to criticism in relation to this matter. The Executive Council of Australian Jewry is correct in saying that the whole episode of war criminals from the Second World War in relation to Australia—and the approach of all governments—is a very sorry story. The fact is that, during that period after the war, a number of Nazis, fascists and people of very dubious background were allowed into Australia. When I consider the sorts of checks we make now on people who have legitimate reasons to come to Australia, as compared with what we did then with regard to some people whose background and motivation were amazing, I think this matter needed to be examined.

I have been around for a few years. In 1987, thinking that we would be doing something, I supported the bill which set up the commission. By 1992, when there was not a single successful prosecution, those of us who took an interest in the matter were appalled. Not only had it cost the nation several million dollars but, as the honourable member for Denison has now pointed out in relation to this bill, we were frustrated by certain other factors. One was that in every case, rather than dealing with this matter in cooperation with other countries, we thought we would simply deal with it by trying people, or thinking about trying people, under Australian law with Australian practice. They would then have to pass the stricter criteria that are at present in our system.

That would have been okay if our nation and certain sections of our bureaucracy had not covered up the fact that, when these characters came to Australia at that time, some of them knew of their background. Why has there not been an inquiry into this matter? We have all sorts of parliamentary and other inquiries but we have never had an inquiry into this very serious issue—the cover-up of war criminals who came to Australia after the Second World War. Yes, we had a War Crimes Tribunal established, but its business was to find individuals, not to look into the question of what actually happened in the Australian processes that allowed these people to come during that period. This is very serious: I am not sure that we have learnt from our history.

I take this opportunity to say that I hope the parliament at some stage looks into this matter, looking into the role of our intelligence agencies, our immigration department and other bureaucracies that were involved in covering up the fact that some of these people who came out here had been directly responsible for the killing of a large number of innocent people, including Jewish people.

I now turn to the question of what happened when we did form the War Crimes Tribunal and the sorry tale from 1987 to 1992—we never got a single conviction. We have been criticised in international circles about this. I remember that, at the time they wound it up, we were told that we had done our best and we had gone around trying to find information. In the case of the one person they managed to actually get before a court, it did not proceed in the end because they claimed that the information was not sufficiently powerful in relation to our judicial system.

One wonders whether it would not have been better to start up an investigation into what actually happened in terms of the total process rather than set up a narrow tribunal that looked into the prosecution of individuals. Why were all those people who came here—they may since have died or there may not be sufficient evidence of all their misbehaviour—allowed into this country? Why were they not checked? Who covered up for them? We never investigated that.

We are now being told by the minister in her second reading speech that the reason for this amendment is that things have changed in Europe, and that some of the countries that were behind the Iron Curtain are now part of the European family and we therefore needed to make some extradition treaties with them. But there is a problem: we have suddenly discovered that the criterion called the prima facie case that we have in the legislation under section 22 does not apply to all countries. Not all countries have a similar criterion. Why we suddenly discovered this after all these years is an interesting question.

As the honourable member for Blair said earlier, even if we formed these extradition agreements with Latvia, Estonia, Lithuania and several other countries in the former Soviet Union and perhaps even countries in the former Yugoslavia, because they have a different system of dealing with this—that is, a civil code system instead of the same criminal code system of the kind that we have—we still would not be able to get the extraditions going. That is why we want to get rid of section 22. I agree with that; the only thing is that we should have done it years ago. Many of the people who have been guilty of these crimes have now passed away or they are very old, and the possibility of putting together evidence, even under the civil code system, becomes much more difficult.

Having said all that, I think we should now actively take advantage of the passing of this legislation and say that Australia is ready to cooperate with these countries in cases like this. We should, firstly, speedily ensure that we have extradition agreements and, secondly, where there are requests from these countries, deal with them under the civil code system of that particular country so that people can be extradited and dealt with for the things that they have done.

I said earlier that maybe we have not completely learned the lesson of that previous experience. I would be interested to know whether the War Crimes Amendment Bill or the War Crimes Act as it stands will actually be applicable to the crimes against humanity issues that have arisen in relation to a number of places. I am referring particularly to former Yugoslavia. Will this legislation allow us to carry out extraditions against people who may have been involved in crimes against humanity in the former Yugoslavia? Will this legislation ensure that people who may have come from the former Yugoslavia who may be guilty of crimes against humanity are covered by the amended War Crimes Act? I would be interested in the minister's response to this issue.

The terminology has changed in international forums from `war crimes' to `crimes against humanity'. This is important because of what happens in internal civil war type situations. In situations where there are ethnic conflicts within a particular country, there is no formal declaration of war but there are crimes against humanity. Will this amended legislation be able to deal with that sort of issue? If not, I would suggest that we have missed an opportunity to actually get Australia involved in an international effort in relation to these matters.

We have had a number of sensational incidents in relation to this term `crimes against humanity', the most famous being the Pinochet case in Britain, where Spain requested the extradition of the former president and dictator Mr Pinochet for crimes against humanity committed while he was president of his country.

Let us assume that we had a Pinochet type personality here in Australia and a country requested the extradition of that person. Would this legislation, as amended, cover that sort of incident? Would it cover that type of case? If not, why not? If we have amended legislation, why haven't we taken account of this matter in order to deal with that sort of contingency? And you do not have to be a president. You can be a significant player who has been responsible for crimes against humanity in one of these situations—in a civil war, in an ethnic conflict or, as in the Pinochet case, where the crime is against one's own people.

I would be interested to find out whether the amended legislation is going to cover these situations. If not, I would like to say that I am pretty disappointed that it does not and that there ought to have been further amendments to this legislation to deal with that sort of issue. If the intention of this legislation is to overcome bottlenecks in relation to the past, in relation to 30 or 40 years ago, we should also have learnt from the hard lessons of that time and be ready to deal with more contemporary cases.

We are talking now about dealing with crimes against humanity in relation to East Timor. We have made quite a bit of fuss about that, and of course I agree that we ought to be pursuing it. But what about our own legislation? For example, what if somebody from Indonesia manages to become a permanent Australian resident or citizen and it is discovered that that person was involved in East Timor human rights abuses? Would that be covered under this legislation?

I think it is very important that we confront these issues. We do not want to be left with the following comment made by the Vice-President of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry at the end of the Australian process when he said:
Now we have the benefit of 10 years to look at the legislation that was adopted—
that was the 1989 amendments to the War Crimes Act—
we can see that it failed. It not only failed to deal with that one situation, it failed to deal with the other cases.

What is left is a situation where the information, the allegations, the research is all out there and there's still more that can be conceivably done if the government was willing to devote the resources.
Perhaps that point ought to be taken on board as well. Perhaps we have not devoted sufficient resources in the right way when dealing with this issue.

As we move towards the new millennium and we look at casting off some of the worst aspects of our history, one of the worst things in our history has been the fact that war criminals were able to come to Australia and survive here when they had done awful things and that, by the time we got around to doing something about it, many of them had either passed away or the evidence had disappeared. We have not even seriously investigated why all of that happened.

When we are facing up to the future, when we have seen the situations that have occurred in various places around the world, especially in the former Yugoslavia, and we know that there may be people here who have been involved in some of these crimes, let us make sure that we have the weapons, that we have the legislation and that we have the political will to pursue any such people so that we do not repeat the episode which occurred after the Second World War in relation to the Nazis. I support the legislation.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I thank all members who have contributed to this debate. It was pleasing to hear that members of the opposition support the very important amendments contained in the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 . In particular, I was pleased to see the support from the opposition shadow minister for justice and customs, the member for Denison.

speech.para: The member for Calwell, Dr Theophanous, raised a number of important issues. For example, he talked long and hard about the amendments contained in the bill being about 10 years overdue. It is indeed a shame that the previous government did not listen to the member for Calwell, who was part of that government. No doubt he called for those sorts of amendments in his time but the then government did not listen or respond. The good news is that this government has acted very promptly indeed, so we have before us today this bill which repeals section 22. This bill was introduced in 1998 but it lapsed when parliament was prorogued and it has been reintroduced very promptly following the re-election of the government. On that front, I should think that the member for Calwell is somewhat better pleased with the performance of this government in relation to the matter.

The member for Calwell was also very concerned in that he felt there had never been in this country any investigation of potential bureaucratic cover-up in relation to alleged war criminals slipping through the net immediately after the Second World War, and since, coming into this country. He alleged that perhaps there was some bureaucratic cover-up at that time and there had never been any concern from any government of the day to check allegations which I presume have been made over a number of years.

Under Prime Minister Robert Menzies there was an independent inquiry which looked at whether or not there was any incompetence or deliberate cover-up in terms of people coming to this country who were potential or alleged war criminals. I refer the member to Parliamentary Paper No. 90/1987, which will give him access to the findings of that inquiry. I will read briefly from paragraph (3) of the section headed `Findings':

While Australian officers in Europe endeavoured to prevent the acceptance for migration to Australia of persons responsible for war crimes, and these endeavours must have prevented many war criminals from entering Australia, there were serious limitations, particularly in early years, in numbers and geographical spread of staff available to do the necessary checking and equally serious gaps in the data against which Australian security officers would have made their checks, particularly in relation to non-Germans. These limitations and gaps would have made possible the entry of persons responsible for war crimes although the number of persons so admitted would have been a minute proportion of the enormous number of persons who migrated to Australia in the post-war years.
Paragraph (4) refers to chapter 7 of the report in the following terms:

. . . no person admitted into Australia under arrangements with U.K. or U.S. intelligence agencies, to the knowledge of Australian authorities, appears to have been the object of charges or allegations as to commission of war crimes although there is a possibility that, particularly before 1956, former employees of such agencies may have entered Australia without the knowledge of Australian authorities.
Certainly, the Liberal government of the day tried very hard to sort out if there were problems deliberately perpetrated when it came to letting people into this country who should not be here.

The member for Melbourne Ports was most concerned about the US current affairs program 20/20, which screened last week. It suggested that it is quite an easy thing to live in Australia as a war criminal. The member for Melbourne Ports was quite rightly concerned about Australia's reputation if that sort of thing were true, and he seemed to think that that in fact was the case. That television program was followed up last week by the 7.30 Report.

Of course, the member for Melbourne Ports, like the US 20/20 producers and Australia's own 7.30 Report producers, failed to stress the fact that we have very different systems in place when it comes to how we go about prosecuting alleged war criminals. For example, the US uses the Immigration Nationality Act 1952, which allows for the deportation of any alien who was simply associated with the Nazi government or any area occupied by the forces of that government with any established Nazi assistance. There is no need to prove a suspect has any personal involvement in any war crime. The proceedings are civil. So the association has to be proved only on the balance of probabilities. As well, if the suspect concealed wartime activities when applying for a US visa and that concealment was found to be a wilful and material misrepresentation, then that is also additional grounds for deportation.

On the other hand, Australia must, under the War Crimes Act 1945, prove the actual commission of a war crime within the meaning of the act or an ancillary offence such as aiding and abetting beyond a reasonable doubt, and it is subject to rigorous criminal, evidentiary and procedural requirements. The suspects have the same rights in Australia under the law as any other Australian suspected of committing a serious crime. So the Australia government of the day—and I think most of us would agree it would continue—was concerned that the fairness of the Australian criminal justice system should not be perverted for the sake of easy popular convictions based on inadequate evidence.

Deportation was not an easy option under Australian law. Until 1998, there was a limit of 10 years before the commission of an offence of giving false information in applying for Australian citizenship after which a person would no longer be liable for deportation for that offence. In 1998, our government removed that time limit, but the effect of the amendment was prospective only. Therefore, people who have already received the benefit of the time limit cannot be deported now under the amended provision. I hope that the member for Melbourne Ports understands that we have different systems. It is easy to say that the US has many points and Australia zero, but that is comparing apples and pears. Let me reiterate that the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1999 deals with very serious issues of a long time ago, but time has not indeed dimmed any Australian's sense of justice when it comes to prosecuting and assisting with prosecutions of those alleged of war crimes.

Section 22 imposes a specific requirement for the content of extradition requests to Australia with respect to conduct which would be covered by the act—in other words, certain crimes committed in Europe during World War II. Currently such requests must be accompanied by the presentation of evidence which establishes a prima facie case that the person has committed the alleged war crime. The main justification for the repeal of section 22 is that it is no longer appropriate to include this onerous requirement for war crime extraditions, particularly following the emergence of newly independent states in Europe from behind the Iron Curtain.

In principle, Australia is interested in establishing modern extradition arrangements with these countries which have now been accepted as members of the Council of Europe. So the enactment of this bill, together with the completion of these new modern extradition arrangements, will increase significantly our ability to cooperate with other countries which seek our assistance in bringing alleged World War II criminals to trial. I think all Australians would be with us today in agreeing that this is a very important amendment. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debate.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Today I would like to pay tribute to all the members of the Lilley Pricewatch team. They do important work detecting price rises in supermarkets. They act as a thermometer detecting heat seeking price rises.

speech.para: The Pricewatch surveys were commenced by my predecessor, Mrs Elaine Darling, and they have been carried on by me since 1993. From relatively humble beginnings, the survey has expanded to a total of 27 supermarkets located within and adjacent to the electorate of Lilley, which is situated in the northern suburbs of Brisbane. A fixed basket of 38 grocery items is surveyed at irregular periods by a group of volunteers. Naturally, we have no prior knowledge of any promotions or specials involving items included in our basket and we record both the everyday shelf price and a special price, if applicable.

We take extreme care to ensure the accuracy of our surveys. On receipt, they are scanned to establish whether any apparent errors are recorded. If uncertainty exists, a second check of the store is carried out. The results are maintained on spreadsheets which provide the data to enable an analysis to be carried out. For much of this year, we have been reporting price increases at a rate three times the increase in the CPI and that is a matter of extreme concern.

In particular, I would like to pay tribute to a number of people from the Pricewatch team: Mavis Sinclair, Gaye Tatasciore, Edwina Anderson, Valmai Fisher, Carol Langfield, Brigit Langer, Eunice Jenkin, Bernie Kingston, Louin Wright, Noeline Coran, Sylvia Davey, Gregory Hughes, Christine Gordan, Ben Thompson, Gwen Thomas, Janette Ryan, Bobby Flanagan and Jules Shegog, Joan Ross, Claire Don, Rona Belton, Lola Palmsellers, Karina King, Ailsa Tryst, Gwenneth Smith, Maisie Llwellyen, Donna Smart, Louise Koster and Janette Bohan.

The other thing that there is a lot of community concern about is increases in the price of milk. This year, in Brisbane, the price of milk has risen something like 12 per cent, and that is when there has been an official inflation rate of 1.1 per cent. The price of a litre of milk was $1.17 at the beginning of this year and it is now $1.32. Many people living in the northern suburbs of Brisbane are extremely concerned and have written to me about this matter. For example, a letter from Taigum said:

I am thoroughly disgusted at the increases in milk prices. We have two children to encourage to drink plenty of milk so they grow up healthy and have strong bones and teeth, but the more it costs to buy each week, the less I encourage them to drink.
From Boondall:

My husband and I receive a Carer's Pension and are caring for three intellectually disabled people (also on Pensions) in our own home. We have no other source of revenue—savings or super. If these types of price rises continue and are not off-set by pension rises, we will soon find it impossible to care for our charges.
From Deagon:

With the rise in the price of milk, we are now in a situation where it is cheaper to give our children Cocoa-Cola than to provide them with this necessary nutrition of milk, and have no doubt this will happen with the poorer people of our country.

People are being savaged by price rises. I am extremely concerned that this is yet another example of price increases being introduced ahead of the GST. If price increases on milk are already outstripping inflation 10 times over, what will happen to the price of milk when the rate of inflation is five per cent, as has been predicted by analysts like the Commonwealth Bank and now the Reserve Bank? KPMG, in a government sponsored study, have already predicted a GST from 1 July will add at least 7.5 per cent to food prices and this will be on top of the pre-GST price rises currently hitting consumers.

If the Howard government and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission cannot protect families from price hikes on basic dietary necessities like milk and bread before the GST is introduced, I am extremely concerned at what actions we can expect in a post-GST environment.

Following the increase in the price of milk, I decided to look at the legislation to see whether the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission would do anything about it. I was surprised to find that they could do nothing about it unless there was a special reference from the Treasurer to the ACCC about milk in Brisbane. Accordingly, I have written to the Treasurer, Mr Costello, saying:

. . . I earnestly request that you exercise your powers under s.18(1) of the Prices Surveillance Act 1983 and require the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission to hold an enquiry into the two price rises by Pauls Limited and the two rises announced by Dairy Farmers which have occurred since deregulation. Although the rises did not coincide exactly, they became effective within one week of each other.

The terms of reference should include an investigation into the possibility of collusion in setting prices and also whether Pauls Limited is using its pre-eminent market strength to manipulate the Brisbane market.
(Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: National Gallery of Australia: Sensation Exhibition

talk.start.para: —National institutions are important windows into the character of a country. They are literally the embodiment of the historical, social and artistic standards of its people. Quite rightly, we take enormous pride in institutions like the High Court, Questacon, cultural vehicles like the Australian Opera, the Australian Ballet and the Sydney and Melbourne symphony orchestras or, for that matter, repositories like the National Library and the Australian War Memorial.

speech.para: No less so should be our National Art Gallery. What it displays of Australian art is a window into the artistic and cultural qualities of Australia. Equally, what it displays from overseas is Australia's endorsement of what citizens of this country see and appreciate. A national gallery should be showing the best of the best. That said, I heartily endorse the action of the National Gallery Director, Dr Brian Kennedy, in cancelling the Sensation exhibition. This is an exhibition which features an image of the Virgin Mary splattered with elephant dung, a wall-sized portrait of a convicted child killer, a cow's head live with maggots, dead animals in formaldehyde and a head sculpted from an artist's blood—hardly edifying stuff.

I am no prude and, in broad terms, I abhor censorship, but this country needs to preserve certain mores, and there are times when we should draw a line in the sand. For example, we do not tolerate the depiction or promotion of paedophilia in any art or film form. In fact, a bill which will shortly be before us will not even allow young adults to be used to represent or depict paedophilia. I also believe that we should not tolerate the denigration of religious symbols of any religion. I supported the decision to remove the Serrano photographic exhibition in 1997 and, on similar grounds, I support this decision to reject the Sensation exhibition.

It is one thing to take the mickey out of the pomposity of the clergy as Dave Allen was wont to do in his TV programs, but it is totally different to depict the foremost symbol of Christianity in an immersion of urine as Serrano did. This is about the most offensive depiction imaginable to any practising Christian. To represent the Virgin Mary with elephant dung is equally offensive. If these images are not blasphemous, what is?

We have no established religion—quasi or otherwise in this country—nor would I advocate it for one moment, yet it would be fair to say that many of our laws, our legislative procedures, the conduct of our universities and our military traditions have their genesis in the Christian tradition. While this should not be lorded over citizens who are atheists, humanists or from other religious traditions, it is entitled to be treated with equal respect. Our Jewish and Muslim communities object to any denigration of their religious or cultural traditions or symbols, and they are quite entitled to do so. But it seems to be fashionable by some in the arts community and the media to denigrate Christian symbols with some of the most outrageous and offensive depictions of these Christian symbols, and that is what is happening with this exhibition called Sensation.

The Sensation exhibition denigrates not only Christian symbols but also the quality of young artists. Apparent justification for exhibitions such as Sensation has gone along the lines that it is the duty of the gallery, as a national institution, to show young artists of another country and what they are doing. But, as art critic Giles Auty said in the Australian on 30 November, the objection here is that the art collected by the exhibition coordinator, Charles Saatchi, is not generally typical of anything at all.

The images depicted by the artists in this exhibition are, at best, on the fringe of artistic acceptance. They are simply trying to gain attention by being outrageous. Allowing work like that to be included in our national gallery does not send a positive image to our youth and denigrates the standing of a fine national institution.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to address the question which has received increasing media attention, that of databases and the concern that many Australians have about what information is being stored about them and for what purpose. I want to use two examples today. The first is the decision by Centrelink to outsource to a direct marketing company, Salmat, the information which will be sent to Centrelink clients. This decision needs to be put in the context of the Auditor-General's report on privacy in Centrelink which drew attention to a number of inadequacies there and noted that they could not give a report on outsourced activities from Centrelink because they simply did not have access.

speech.para: This is quite a serious issue. This company will now have access to 6½ million names. The contract is worth some $32 million. Of great concern is that, as I understand it, at the time that the contract was given to Salmat, they were under Federal Police investigation for fraud. So there is a great deal of concern about the security of customers' details and information as a result of this decision by the government.

The second issue I wish to raise is that of tenancy databases. As you may be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, there are a number of private companies that hold personal information about tenants. Tens of thousands of tenants are listed on these databases, which contain information collected from tenants at the time they apply for a rental property. These databases can then be accessed by agents and landlords for a fee as a way of checking the rental history of the individual. Commonly known as bad tenant databases, the principal objective of these is to pass information between agents and landlords about the desirability of different tenants.

The principal problem with these databases is that lack of regulation enables database operators to list tenants with no proof of any wrongdoing by the tenant. Moreover, once tenants find themselves on such databases, they find extreme difficulty in having themselves removed, whether or not they are responsible. An ongoing case in Sydney underlines the problems associated with the operation of tenancy databases.

Mrs Christine Lindsay, of Baulkham Hills, is a small business owner who is currently in rental accommodation. Due to her hectic schedule she has in the past paid her rent a couple of days late, but she has always been able to pay and she has never defaulted on her rent for the fortnight. The practice between the agent and herself has been that if her rent is late the agent has called her and she has been able to run down to the office and pay her fortnightly rent. However, Mrs Lindsay's real estate agents have now joined TICA, a default tenancy control system. In November this year Mrs Lindsay was 14 days late with her rent. Instead of the normal friendly phone call, she received a threatening letter in the mail from TICA. The letter informed her that her debt had been placed on the national tenancy database. The letter then stated:
Due to your actions you may now find difficulties in freely obtaining rental accommodation.

It went on to say that she might have problems obtaining credit in the future. This terrifying letter was delivered to a small business woman who was just 14 days overdue and has always paid her rent in the past. She had no ability to find out whether her name had been removed from the list.

Indeed, in order to check whether your name is on the tenancy database, you need to call the company and give them your current address and drivers licence number, thus providing the database company with even more personal information than they may already have. For the privilege, you will charged $4.95 per minute from a regular phone and more from mobile phones. It is in the database company's interest to have more names on the list, rather than fewer. Member organisations pay to look up names and, in some circumstances, pay if the database company is able to find the tenant's name on their list.

In other instances, they have been listed on databases when they have never even lived at the property where the breach was supposed to have occurred and have found it difficult to have themselves removed. Moreover, there are no clear regulations about the maximum length of time that a tenant is to be listed. Tenants might find themselves on lists many years after the supposed breach is committed.

I understand that a series of national privacy principles have been proposed as part of a current review of the Federal Privacy Act. However, the Privacy Commissioner has stated that the legislation will be complaint driven rather than provide protection through proper regulation over the sensitive area of the collection and transfer of personal information. Apart from the discrimination against those who are often the weakest link in the housing chain, tenancy databases and their inherent problems highlight some of the broader issues surrounding privacy regulation in Australia. This parliament should not support private companies being able to develop highly sophisticated and extensive databases on Australian citizens. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak about an issue that the residents of Kurnell are facing. The federal government has in place a program which covers the cost of insulating houses which are subject to aircraft noise levels at or above the 30 Australian Noise Exposure Forecast, ANEF, and also schools and churches which experience considerable noise exposure. Residents in my electorate living in the suburb of Kurnell experience noise which is in the 20 to 25 ANEF range, and as such are not compensated for noise insulation they may wish to undertake in their homes.

speech.para: I think that this is unfair. The residents of Kurnell experience more aircraft noise than any other area in the entire confines of Sydney and also more than any other in Australia as 55 per cent of all aircraft go over Kurnell. The latest figures show that between 52 and 53 per cent of all aircraft go over Kurnell, yet the residents get no compensation for insulation of their houses at all because they fall just outside that requirement.

People wishing to build houses or an extension in Kurnell must comply with a whole gamut of building regulations of the Sutherland Shire Council, which ensures safety and privacy from neighbours, conformity with the general style of surrounding buildings and so on. They must also comply with Australian Standard 2021, which relates to aircraft noise insulation. This standard dictates that new properties within a 20 to 25 ANEF contour must be insulated against aircraft noise. This is a requirement of the state government regional environmental plan No. 17, clause 23(2). On a typical house, such as the one proposed for construction by Kevin Davis of Kurnell, noise insulation measures cost around $45,000. Some noise measures include installing two windows and one frame and the hiring of acoustic engineers, for example.
I find it grossly unfair that residents are forced to pay such high costs. I have a letter from Mr Kevin Davis who intends to build a new house in Kurnell. He writes:

A condition of our building approval from the Sutherland Shire Council, is to provide noise insulation measures Australian Standard AS2021. Apparently this is a requirement of the State Government Regional Environmental Plan No. 17 Clause 23(2).
We have now let a contract for the construction of our house and our Builder has given us a written statement that the aircraft noise insulation measures cost $58,650.
Some of the noise measures are quite extensive.

What we have in this situation is a double whammy: on the one hand, 53 per cent of all aircraft take off and land over the residents of Kurnell, yet they do not receive anything for noise insulation; on the other hand, when they build an extension or a new home, they are subject to massive costs not experienced anywhere else in Sydney. I think this is grossly unfair. It is time that the various government authorities come together to solve this problem for the residents of Kurnell.

talk.start.para: —The Ipswich region has for some time received unfavourable media and negative publicity from a variety of sources. This has caused many people—including me—in our community to be concerned with the perceptions and the images of the region and the city of Ipswich. I could go on about how hard done by we are or how it is not fair that we cop more than our fair share of negative projections and images of where live, but there is clearly no use in complaining or hoping that just by ignoring the issue it will go away or somehow change will occur unaided.

speech.para: There is a real spirit of pride in the community of Ipswich, in the Ipswich City Council and in the Ipswich business community, which have united in an endeavour to positively change the image of the Ipswich region. Ipswich is a city that has been part of the shaping of Queensland, a city steeped in a history that is very much part of its future. But it is also a city that is at the forefront of regional change and innovation, preparing to take the region and its residents well into the 21st century.

To achieve this change, the city of Ipswich through its council will be launching a campaign to highlight the strengths, character, history and achievements of this great region. Sometimes the best way to bring about change is to start by leading. That lead will come from positive efforts to address and eradicate negative media perceptions of the area.

One of the biggest problems we have is that some in the media, and sometimes even some of our own people, have been the city's harshest critics. It is time for all of us to turn that around and push for a balance and for positive images to be portrayed in place of the negatives that are always existent if you do not work hard enough to see the positives.

By increasing awareness, we can build pride in our local communities and, by uniting local and diverse interest groups, we can promote common good. Through the Pride campaign the city will build confidence in visitor experiences, and that will involve acknowledging our many heritage sights and places of interest to all Australians.

Ipswich is very similar to many regional cities throughout Australia. It has colourful people, colourful places and an abundance of potential. For that potential to be realised, we will need to use all of these assets to promote and build a new image. Any good campaign must also be backed by the people. And there is no more positive way to show support than through buying local goods and services. This will attract new business, trade and investment and increase economic activity, which will in turn create jobs and help build a strong vibrant tourism industry.

I am confident in saying that Ipswich is well and truly on the map—and for all the right reasons. It is the first city to have launched the global information links concept, a true innovation well ahead of its time. GIL, as it is affectionately known, has delivered on actually bringing Internet services and information to the region even before it became popular in recent government proposals.

Ipswich has a cutting edge interactive gallery called GAL, based on delivering the latest technology and delivering services for a changing expectation. Ipswich has a new university and a new racetrack, which recently hosted the seventh round of the Shell Touring Car series as well as having the Willowbank International Speedway. Ipswich is truly a city that is on the move.

Beyond all of this, our city has a great sense of community. We do things for ourselves. We have fantastic community groups, large numbers of volunteers that donate their time to others and community based organisations that work hard to make living in this region better for all. And their work should be more loudly applauded.

It is incumbent on every stakeholder in Ipswich to play their role. I call on our local media to take a new approach in reporting many of the positive events that occur in our city. I call on all our elected representatives in all levels of government, regardless of their political persuasion, to sweep in 2000 with a rejuvenated approach to our region, and to promote the city in all of their dealings.

I call on our business leaders to be confident of the business potential they have within their reach, to compete hard with other cities like Brisbane and, especially, to never sell themselves short on what they can deliver for this region. Ipswich has many businesses that can take on the world, and many of them actually do win. I call on all our community and church leaders to promote the good work they do and be proud of the services they provide in our community.

Finally, I call on every resident of Ipswich to take every opportunity to participate in the Ipswich Pride campaign. It is their efforts in the end that will make all the difference. I look forward to a bright and prosperous future for the city. Ipswich is truly the smart city, the cultural city and the heritage city. It is a city constantly on the move.

talk.start.para: —Today I rise to speak in support of the introduction of daylight saving to put a halt to the confusion and inconvenience experienced by many residents in south-east Queensland and in my electorate of McPherson. I call on the Queensland government and, in particular, Labor Premier Peter Beattie to take a stand and introduce daylight saving to bring the south-eastern corner of the state into line with other major cities on the eastern seaboard. The situation between the Tweed and Gold Coast is simply ridiculous once again as we enter the summer months.

speech.para: South-east Queensland residents are behind the eight ball by being an hour behind New South Wales, Victoria and Hobart during the summer months. Without a doubt, residents of south-east Queensland want this confusion to end. They want a stop to the inconvenience, the puzzlement and the exasperation.

Residents and business people in south-east Queensland are suffering. Business is particularly affected, and people living and working on opposite sides of the border experience confusion and major inconveniences which impact on family life. There is also no doubt that, for the sake of tourism, daylight saving is absolutely necessary.

In a poll conducted last week by our city's metropolitan daily newspaper, the Gold Coast Bulletin, almost two-thirds, 64 per cent, of residents responded by saying they wanted daylight saving introduced. Only 30 per cent voted against the idea. Seven years ago, when a referendum was held on the issue, the result was similar: 66 per cent voted yes in 1992 and 33 per cent voted no. Unfortunately, the rest of Queensland voted against daylight saving so it was not implemented. There is no doubt what the people of south-east Queensland want, but the Premier of Queensland is just not listening.

Mr Beattie has told Gold Coast residents that during this term of office he will not address their concerns on the daylight saving issue. He has said that he will hold a referendum on the issue if he is re-elected for a second term. These comments are not good enough. Queensland needs to introduce daylight saving immediately for the economic benefit of south-east Queensland residents and business people. The Premier needs to give serious consideration to bringing the south-east corner in line with other major cities on the eastern seaboard. Referendums are extremely costly and do not immediately address the problem of daylight saving. In addition, with the Olympics coming up, different time zones are going to cause confusion for athletes and visitors to our nation.

I have also called on the state member for Currumbin, Mary Rose, to lobby the Premier for his support in putting a stop to this confusion at the border. As the only government state member on the Gold Coast, Mrs Rose has a responsibility to address the concerns of residents and business people in south-east Queensland. I strongly support comments made by the Prime Minister last week suggesting a shake-up of Australian time zones. Under the current system, Australia has four different time zones over summer, which makes life more than a little difficult. Under such a move, south-east Queensland would move to daylight saving with Sydney, Melbourne and Hobart. For the sake of residents and business people in south-east Queensland, daylight saving needs to be introduced as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —To continue my speech this morning on illegal immigrants, I would now like to quote a letter from Mr John Gordon which was published in the Advertiser on Tuesday, 30 November 1999. The letter is entitled `Think Twice', and it sums up the feelings of many of my constituents in Makin. It states:

speech.para: So it may be tough on the illegal immigrants, boat people or whatever they are called when they are housed in solid construction buildings at Woomera. They should be given the same conditions that I and hundreds of other workers at the construction camps at Phillip Ponds, Koolymilka and Woomera West had to put up with in the `50's. Two men shared a tent and we were issued with an iron trundle bed, mattress, pillow, two blankets, no linen, a kerosene lantern, washbowl, enamel plates (two of), knife, fork and spoon.

To shower we had to hand pump water up into a showerhead, and if it was cold we had to light a fire under a copper and then pump. We were allowed two bottles of beer every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. Wine and spirits were a prohibited import but some was smuggled in. We survived and built the rocket range. These conditions may make illegal persons think twice about coming. Molly-coddling them and making them feel at home is like putting out the welcoming mat. Turn the boats around or tow them back to the ports they came from—that would be a far bigger deterrent.

I can confirm that these conditions experienced by Mr John Gordon and others is true, as my father as a legal migrant to this country in the 1950s also lived in a tent for two years while he helped build railways at Islington in Adelaide, South Australia.

talk.start.para: —I want to read briefly from the Northern District Times of this week, which says in its opening paragraph, page 3:

speech.para: Telopea Post Office made history on Monday after becoming the only branch to survive closure and reopen its doors thanks to the remarkable community support.

I want to thank Bruce Darley from Darley's Butchers in Telopea, Bernie Smith from the Telopea Newsagency and Susan Salt from the Telopea Hair Studio. In particular, I want to thank my Labor local government colleague, Lord Mayor David Borger, who worked very closely with us in a remarkable community campaign to turn around the monolith of Australia Post and to refocus on its local customers. That is what happened in Telopea. I want to invite all Australians to come to the street party which will be held at the Telopea shopping centre on Friday, 17 December at 4 p.m. to celebrate what is a great milestone in people power, in community activism. It is a great success story for one gutsy local community.

talk.start.para: —The time allowed for the debate has expired. The committee stands adjourned until a day and hour to be announced by the Deputy Speaker.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Are persons under age 60 but in receipt of income support excluded from the proposed one-off Aged Persons Savings Bonus; if so, why.
(2) Are retirees and those on support payments, who are aged under age 60 excluded from the bonus; if so, why.
(3) Has he received advice that the age 60 limit is not discriminatory; if so, what are the details.
(4) Is it possible to include certain groups of payments within the guidelines so that those genuinely retired under age 60 are included in the bonus provisions; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The amended answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Persons aged under 60 years in receipt of Commonwealth income support payments will receive a 4 per cent increase in those payments on 1 July 2000. Other associated allowances such as the pharmaceutical allowance and the mobility allowance will also increase by 4 per cent and the maximum rent assistance rate will increase by 7 per cent from 1 July 2000.

(2) See answer to (1). In addition, persons aged under age 60 can benefit from significant reductions in personal income tax. If those persons have dependent children they can also benefit from the families package component of the new tax system. Self-funded retirees aged 55 or more who are not in receipt of a Commonwealth income support payment will be eligible to receive the Self-Funded Retirees Supplementary Bonus which provides a one-off, non-taxable payment of up to $2,000 for a single self-funded retiree or up to $2,000 each for a self-funded retiree couple.
(3) See answer to (1) and (2).

(4) The Government's new tax system is designed so that all Australians share in the benefit of tax reform. Persons genuinely retired under age 60 can benefit from elements of the new tax system such as the income tax cuts; the Self-Funded Retirees Supplementary Bonus; the 30 per cent private health insurance rebate/benefit introduced on 1 January 1999; and redesigned company tax ar rangements, whereby excess imputation credits will be refundable to resident taxable individuals and complying superannuation funds.

subdebateinfo.title: International Conventions, Agreements and Treaties: Implementation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 874)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 August 1999:

question.para: What international (a) conventions, (b) treaties and (c) agreements have been implemented by federal legislation since the answer to question No 764 (Hansard , 21 November 1996, page 7361).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I note that the honourable member has asked for this information in a series of questions going back some years. In the Government's response to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee report Trick or Treaty? Commonwealth Power to Make and Implement Treaties, a commitment was made to provide an annual list to the Parliament of Commonwealth legislation specifically implementing treaties. The complete lists for 1996-1997 have been compiled and are set out below. The 1998 list is under preparation and will be tabled as soon as possible.

I am informed that the following Acts passed by the Federal Parliament during 1996 and 1997 expressly implemented international conventions, treaties or agreements. Included under the name of each Act is a brief explanation setting out the relevant international convention, treaty or agreement or other matter of international law.
Dairy Produce Amendment Act 1996 (No 3 of 1996)

This Act complements the Dairy Produce Levy (No 1) Amendment Act 1996 in providing the legal framework for the administration of the dairy market support scheme by the Australian Dairy Corporation. The provisions of the Act revise the definitions of market milk and manufacturing milk, by reference to the Dairy Produce Levy (No 1) Amendment Act 1996 to allow the established milk payment practices of the dairy industry to continue unchanged and to remain consistent with the World Trade Organisation Agreement.Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Act 1996 (No 4 of 1996)

This Act introduced minor but necessary amendments to ensure consistency between industry milk payment practices and the dairy market support legislation. Following the Uruguay round of trade negotiations, Australia introduced new arrangements from 1 July 1995 to deliver assistance to dairy producers through a clearly defined and transparent domestic support scheme. Administration of the scheme by the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) is on the basis of industry milk payment practices which were not consistent with the legislation. This Act retrospectively aligned the market support legislation with the administrative arrangements of the ADC. The market support arrangements remain consistent with the World Trade Organisation Agreement.
Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1996 (No 7 of 1996)

This Act amended the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1989 to ensure that Australia can discharge its obligations under international instruments relating to the control of transboundary movements of hazardous waste. The Basel Convention was drafted to cover the process of final disposal and recovery operations of hazardous waste, and both kinds of processes are included in the Convention definitions under the single term `disposal'. The principal Act had to be widened to cover a wide range of hazardous wastes from which valuable materials are to be recovered. Amending the Act remedied the discrepancy between our international obligations and our domestic legislation.
Customs Tariff (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1996 (No 15 of 1996)

The Act introduced changes to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. The 1995 Tariff Act reflected some 350 changes to the International Convention on the Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System of the World Customs Organisation in 1993. Australia became a party to the Convention in 1987. The 1995 Tariff Act gave effect to Australia's obligations to align its tariff structure with the international standard. The 1987 Tariff Act was repealed by Part 3 of the 1995 Tariff Act with effect from 1 July 1996. Schedule 1 of this Act allows for the update of all references from the 1987 Tariff Act to the 1995 Tariff Act and its corresponding provisions to ensure their continued effectiveness. Schedule 2 allows a similar update to several types of instruments such as by-laws and Tariff Concession Orders.
Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Act (No 1) 1996 (No 18 of 1996)

This Act introduced amendments to various Acts for which the then Department of Primary Industries and Energy had responsibility including the Offshore Minerals Act 1994 ('Minerals Act'). Section 15 of the Minerals Act was amended to preserve the integrity of licences granted under the Act, the boundaries of which might be affected by changes in the location of the territorial sea baseline. Previously the section applied only where changes to the baseline might be caused by natural processes such as tides or storms. The amendment expanded the section to apply it to changes in the location of the baseline resulting from acquisition of new data or reconsideration of existing data.
Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Act 1996 (No 20 of 1996)

This Act amended the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act 1990. This amendment allowed the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA), amongst other things, to work more cooperatively with international sports organisations to conduct tests both at major sporting events and out of competition on an annual basis. It further enhanced the role of ASDA in aiming to eliminate drugs in sport in line with anti-doping agreements that Australia has concluded with other countries, including the United Kingdom, Canada, France, New Zealand and Norway, and is in line with the Council of Europe Anti-Doping Convention to which Australia has acceded.
Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Amendment Act 1996 (No 26 of 1996)

This amendment to the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Act 1991 allowed the Government to collect the full telecommunications carriers' share of the United Nations International Telecommunication Union (ITU) contribution. The unamended Act would not have allowed this as the collection of the full telecommunications carriers' share of the ITU contribution would have exceeded the amount provided for under the Act. The ITU is a UN specialised agency which is concerned with international cooperation in the use of telecommunications and the radio frequency spectrum.
Crimes Amendment (Controlled Operations) Act 1996 (No. 28 of 1996)

This Act amended the Crimes Act 1914 to exempt from criminal liability certain law enforcement officers who engage in `controlled operations' to obtain evidence of offences relating to narcotic goods and related purposes. The Act gave effect to certain provisions in the UN Convention against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances 1988, which deals with controlled operations to counter organised and sophisticated traffickers.
Australian Law Reform Commission Act 1996 (No 32 of 1996)

One provision of this Act requires the Law Reform Commission to aim at ensuring that the laws, proposals and recommendations it reviews, considers or makes are, as far as practicable, consistent with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and that in performing its functions it pays regard to all of Australia's relevant international obligations.
Taxation Laws Amendment (International Tax Agreements) Act 1996 (No 39 of 1996)

This Act gave legislative force to the provisions of the double taxation agreement between the Australian Commerce and Industry Office and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office signed on 29 May 1996 in Canberra. The Act inserted the text of the Agreement into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as a schedule to that Act.
Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation Amendment Act 1996 (No 40 of 1996)

This Act regulates the provision by Australia of international assistance in criminal matters when certain requests are made by a foreign country, and it facilitates the obtaining by Australia of international assistance in criminal matters. The Act applies to all foreign countries unless the Regulations provide that it is subject to any mutual assistance treaty between that country and Australia and any multilateral mutual assistance treaty (being a treaty to which that country is a party).
Airports Act 1996 (No 42 of 1996)

This Act provides the legislative framework for granting leases to airport specific companies and the transfer of assets and obligations associated with those airport operations from the Federal Airports Corporation. The Act provides for Australia to require airport operators to meet international airservice obligations, and if necessary, specific regulations can be made to this effect. A specific object of the Act is the implementation of international obligations relating to airports such as those contained in the Convention on International Civil Aviation.
Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Act (No 2) 1996 (No 59 of 1996)

This Act introduced amendments to a number of Acts for which the then Department of Primary Industries and Energy was responsible. These amendments include the repeal of the International Sugar Agreement Act 1978. The latter Act approved appropriations for the purpose of giving effect to the International Sugar Agreement 1977.

These amendments also concerned the management of chemicals subject to import and export restrictions under international obligations such as the prior informed consent procedures. Obtaining information from the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals is a part of this management role.
Workplace Relations and other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 (No 60 of 1996)

This Act provides a framework for cooperative workplace relations which promote the economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia by, inter alia, respecting and valuing the diversity of the work force through the prevention and elimination of discrimination and by assisting in giving effect to Australia's international obligations in relation to labour standards.
Carriage of Goods by Sea Amendment Act 1997 (No.123 of 1997)

This Act amended the Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1991 ('1991 Act') which introduced a regime of marine cargo liability intended to be equitable and efficient, compatible with arrangements existing in countries that are major trading partners of Australia, and to take into account developments within the United Nations in relation to marine cargo liability. The Act removed the trigger from the 1991 Act for implementing the Hamburg Rules (Articles 1 to 26 of the United Nations Convention on the Carriage of Goods by Sea) and replaced it with a mechanism for regular review regarding international adoption of the Hamburg Rules. In addition, this Act added to the 1991 Act a regulation-making power which enables a number of other amendments to be made to the way the amended Hague Rules, relating to carrier liability for loss or damage to marine cargoes (Articles 1 to 10 of the International Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules of Law relating to Bills of Lading 1924), operate in Australia.
Customs Tariff Amendment Act (No.2) 1997 (No.192 of 1997)

This Act introduced changes to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. The amendments contained in Schedule 2 of this Act abolished the Canadian margin of preference on certain petrochemical products. These changes took effect from 1 January 1997. Concerns had been expressed for some time regarding the overall balance of benefits under the Canada-Australia Trade Agreement, CANATA. CANATA provides for the exchange of tariff preferences on a range of products traded between the two countries. Following consideration of these and other related issues, CANATA preferential rates of duty were removed from Canadian imports of certain petrochemical products.

Schedule 4 of this Act contains amendments which abolished customs duty on imported sugar and certain sugar by-products and implements Australia's tariff obligations under the Information Technology Agreement. The Agreement seeks the elimination of tariffs on technology and telecommunications products by the year 2000. Schedule 4 of this Act also contains amendments that reinstated the intended tariff assistance on surgical drapes and clarified our international tariff obligations in regard to certain types of lamps and power supply units for computers.
Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Act 1997 (No. 118 of 1997)

The Act amended the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Act 1981 ('the Sea Dumping Act') to bring it in line with current sea dumping practice and to ensure that Australia can meet its international obligations agreed to at the November 1993 Consultative Meeting of the London Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter ('the London Convention'). Section 35 of Schedule 1 of the Act inserted Schedule 3A—3C into the Sea Dumping Act which concerns phasing out sea disposal of industrial waste, incineration at sea, and disposal at sea of radioactive wastes and other radioactive material, respectively. The Act also made a number of minor technical amendments to the Ozone Protection Act 1989 which implements the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.
Fisheries Legislation Amendment Act 1997 (No. 120 of 1997)

Schedule 3 of this Act amended the Torres Strait Fisheries Act 1984. The Fisheries Legislation Amendment Act governs rights of fishing in waters between Australia and Papua New Guinea, in accordance with agreements made in the Torres Strait Treaty regarding sovereignty and maritime boundaries between the two countries. Clause 1 of Schedule 3 inserted new section 15A into the Act. Section 15A enables the Minister to determine a management plan for a fishery in an area of Australian jurisdiction. A management plan must set out its objectives and methods for achieving these objectives. Amongst other things, a management plan may specify how the fishing capacity of a fishery is to be measured and what fishing capacity is permitted for the fishery.
Foreign Affairs and Trade Legislation Amendment Act 1997 (No. 150 of 1997)
This is an omnibus Act that amended four Acts administered by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The major amendments:

. extended to observers the same standard diplomatic privileges and immunities provided to inspectors carrying out challenge inspections under the Chemical Weapons Convention (amendments to the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1944);

. allowed regulations relating to an international organisation to come into force at the same time as the treaty establishing the organisation comes into force for Australia (amendments to the International Organisations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963);

. tightened the eligibility criteria for international organisations and people connected with those organisations to be entitled to privileges and immunities in Australia (amendments to the International Organisations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963);

. enabled specific privileges and immunities to be extended to international tribunals in accordance with Australia's treaty obligations (amendments to the International Organisations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963);

. implemented the provisions of a Protocol between Australia and the International Atomic Energy Agency to provide for expanded declarations of nuclear and non-nuclear related activities and increased access to locations where nuclear material is customarily used (amendments to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987).
International Monetary Agreements Amendment Act 1997 (No. 127 of 1997)

This Act amended the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 to allow Australia to adhere to the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) New Arrangements to Borrow (NAB), and to simplify the framework for conducting and recording Australia's other financial transactions with the IMF. This reduces the administrative costs associated with these transactions and enhances their transparency. The terms and conditions of the NAB as agreed by the Executive Board of the IMF on 27 January 1997 are scheduled to the principal Act.
International Tax Agreements Amendment Act (No.1) 1997 (No.80 of 1997)

This Act provided legislative authority for the entry into force of an exchange of notes amending the comprehensive Double Taxation Agreement between Australia and Vietnam. The exchange of notes with Vietnam took place on 22 November 1996 and the text forms a Schedule to the principal Act. The notes give effect to Australia's undertaking in 1992, the time the Double Taxation Agreement with Vietnam was signed, that Australia would grant tax sparing for specified Vietnamese tax concessions. Tax sparing describes the situation under which Vietnam offers tax concessions to attract foreign investment. Under the tax sparing credit arrangements, an Australian investor taking advantage of specified tax concessions is deemed to have paid the tax actually forgone by Vietnam for the purposes of Australia's foreign tax credit rules.
International Transfer of Prisoners Act 1997 (No.75 of 1997)

This Act enables Australians and certain other persons having community ties with a State or Territory of Australia who are imprisoned overseas, and foreign nationals imprisoned in Australia, to be returned to their home countries to complete the serving of their sentence, and enables persons who have been convicted by the International Criminal Tribunals for the Former Yugoslavia and Rwanda to be transferred to Australia.
Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Act 1997 (No.34 of 1997)

This Act is an omnibus Act that amended a number of Acts falling within the portfolio of the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice. Schedule 7 of the Act amended the Family Law Act 1975. The amending Act extends the jurisdictions of State and Territory Supreme Courts and the courts of summary jurisdiction to determine matters arising under the regulations on the Convention on Protection of Children and Cooperation in Respect of Intercountry Adoption.
Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Act 1997 (No.126 of 1997)

This Act allows appropriations from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for payments required to be made under the Convention establishing the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA). Australia signed the Convention on 30 September 1996, subject to ratification. MIGA was established on 12 May 1988 as one of the World Bank group of financial institutions designed to encourage the flow of investment to member countries and, in particular, to developing member countries. The functions of MIGA include issuing guarantees against non-commercial risks in respect of investments in a member country which flow from other member countries.
Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Act 1997 (No.76 of 1997)

This Act established a Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Reserve, using some of the proceeds of the partial privatisation of Telstra, to fund environmental projects. These include the National Vegetation Initiative, the Murray-Darling 2001 Project, the National Land and Water Resources Audit, the National Reserve System and the Coasts and Clean Seas Initiative. Australia is a party to a number of international treaties that attempt to redress the decline in the quality of the natural environment and protect the environment from further decline. These include:
. Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer;
. Convention on Biological Diversity;
. Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora;
. Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and their Disposal;
. Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage;
. Framework Convention on Climate Change; and
. Convention on Wetlands of International Importance especially as Waterfowl Habitat.
Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Termination Act 1997 (No.50 of 1997)

This Act terminated the imposition of fees under the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Act 1991. It imposed a licence fee in respect of general and mobile telecommunications licences for the financial year ended 1 July 1997 and increased the limit on licence fees to allow for recovery of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's costs attributable to competition matters arising from its new communications rate. The amount, which is determined under the regulations to this Act, is the proportion of the Commonwealth's contribution to the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) that is recovered from carriers. The ITU is a UN specialist agency concerned with international co-operation in the use of telecommunications and the radio frequency spectrum.
Telecommunications Act 1997 (No.47 of 1997)

This Act implemented the new regulatory framework for the telecommunications industry. Section 366 allows the minister to declare that a specified Convention is binding in relation to the members of a specified class of carrier or carriage service provider and that they must act in a way consistent with Australia's obligations under that the Convention.
Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1997 (No.59 of 1997)

This Act provided for the transition to the new framework by treating acts done under the Telecommunications Act 1991 as if they were done under the corresponding provision in the Telecommunications Act 1997. Section 74 of the 1991 Act applies to carriers who are signatories within the meaning of the Operating Agreement relating to the International Telecommunications Satellite Organisation (INTELSAT) and the Convention on the International Maritime Satellite Organisation (INMARSAT). The Minister may notify those carriers of the general policies of the Government that are to apply in relation to the carrier's performance of its functions as a signatory. Section 365 of the 1997 Act largely mirrors section 74 of the 1991 Act. Clause 64 of this Act continues the operation of any notification under section 74 after 1 July 1997 until a direction is given under section 365 of the 1997 Act.
Transport Legislation Amendment (Search and Rescue Service) Act 1997 (No.130 of 1997)

This Act facilitated the amalgamation of the Commonwealth's civil maritime and aviation search and rescue coordination functions into one national centre, and increased the number of ordinary members on the Board of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority from three to four, allowing for the appointment of an officer of the Department to the Board at the discretion of the Minister. To this end, the Act made consequential amendments to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Act 1900, the Air Services Act 1995 and the Civil Aviation Act 1988. The amalgamation continues to allow Australia to fulfil its obligations under the Convention for the Safety of Life at Sea 1974, the International Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue 1979 and Article 7 of the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation. These Conventions relate to the provision of adequate search and rescue services for persons in distress at sea or in aircraft.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 21 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Has Centrelink changed the way recipients of the Parenting Payment Single are reviewed so that only parents earning income must lodge a review every 12 weeks; if so, why.
(2) What type of information are recipients of Parenting Payment Single now required to include in the 12 weekly reviews.
(3) Is it necessary for Centrelink to have this information for working parents but not for non-working parents; if so, why.

(4) Does treating non-working recipients of Parenting Payment Single more favourably than working recipients encourage parents not to take financial responsibility for themselves and their families; if so, to what extent; if not, why not.
(5) What measures are in place to review the effect of changing the way entitlement to Parenting Payment Single is reviewed.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The previous Parenting Payment Single (PPS) review strategy "over reviewed" sole parents without earnings and the new strategy will be more cost effective, particularly with respect to the cyclical reviews. Customer Service would be improved by eliminating unnecessary and unproductive reviews.

The improvement in face-to-face interviews has been made possible by redirection of resources from the 12 weekly reviews to interviews with all PPS customers eight weeks after date of grant. These reviews have been recognised as a par ticularly effective way of identifying changes in domestic circumstances. Also, as the initial contact with Centrelink can be an emotionally distressing time for PPS customers, the face-to-face interviews will provide Centrelink staff with an opportunity to offer information about services available to assist customers and to remind them of their notification obligations.
(2) The type of information now required as part of the 12 weekly review is the same as in the past, that is, a complete review of entitlement to Parenting Payment.

(3) Centrelink requires the same information from both working and non-working customers. All PPS customers may, at some stage, be requested to complete the information contained in the 12 weekly review form. Sole parents who are not in paid employment may receive the form as part of an annual random sample of 5,000 customers.

(4) By transferring resources to the more effective face-to-face interviews, staff will be able to reinforce customers' obligations and provide details of how Centrelink can assist these customers to find work. Given these interviews will take place at least eight weeks after they have separated from their partner, it is more likely that customers will be receptive to information about becoming financially independent.

In recognition of the pressures faced by sole parents in paid employment, more flexible lodgement options have been made available as part of the new review process. While customers previously had to personally lodge their 12 weekly review forms on one particular day, they now have the option to lodge personally or by mail within a 14 day time frame.

(5) To ensure the modified review process is effective and efficient, Centrelink has developed a set of performance indicators which it is monitoring on a monthly basis. These indicators include the number of reviews undertaken, cancellations, changes in payments and the value of upward or downward variations in payments.
In September 2000, a Post Implementation Review (PIR) will be conducted to evaluate staff and customer feedback on the modified review strategy.
